Beg to differ about there being no old system, Prime Minister.  There was an old system but there was also a service delivery model that went along with it, to oversee and validate all the system operations. Your predecessor eliminated more than 500 Compensation Advisor positions.  That was the mistake, not the new system or the old system.  There was no verification, no thought to exceptions and special circumstances and no thought to quality service delivery because we're public servants, so who cares if the non-revenue-generating-overhead gets paid or not, right? His contempt for the public service was well known, but this is black and white proof.   Your first step in a sustainable solution is to reinstate the departmental (not centralized) compensation advisor function, THEN re-deploy an improved Phoenix.  Stop cheaping out like Harper did because in this case, throwing money at the situation CAN solve the problem. I voted for you. Make it happen.  That's your only job, to make your campaign promises happen.

President   _ thank you, very kindly, for your generous remarks and your warm welcome to the university of Saskatchewan. To you and all of your distinguished academic colleagues at this great institution of higher learning in this country  _ Maire Clarke and members of the council, Chief Bobby Clarke of the FSNI and other chiefs that I recognize throughout the room, and metis leaders as well here this evening, thank you for your welcome, thank you all for coming tonight. Good evening to each and every one of you. I  »ll certainly be glad every time I have the opportunity to be back at the University of Saskatchewan, because it is my alma mater and over the years we  »ve been able to do some interesting projects together, and as Peter has mentioned just in this past year we have presided over projects that will invest in this institution something in excess of 150 million dollars to support learning and innovation and brain power in the University of Saskatchewan, in the Province of Saskatchewan and indeed all around the world. So our relationship is big and it  »s strong, and it  »s good to have this opportunity to kind of show it off to the Prime Minister, so this is always on his radar screen.We  »ve also been able to do some good work this past year working on some great many other projects working with the province of Saskatchewan for mental health and home care. There  »s 500 million dollars for infrastructure and for science. There are trade projects which expand the capacity for Saskatchewan producers of beef and pork and canola to export around the world. There  »s 54 million dollars more for affordable housing in this province. A very important 8.4 billion dollars nationally to invest in indigenous health and infrastructure and education to narrow the life gap between indigenous and non-indigenous Canadians. A big portion of that flows to Saskatchewan simply because of the demographics of this province. And most recently, some very important energy transmission projects that will benefit Saskatchewan in some 20,000 jobs that will be created in Western Canada and some 10 billion dollars in private sector investment.So, some good things have been done. There  »s a lot more to do of course, and in listening to you, the Canadian government learns better about what those things are. The whole world is living today through turbulent and consequential times. A time, an era in the history of the world that demands real leadership. Leadership that motivates and animates and energizes, leadership that engages, listens, accounts. And that is what this particular Prime Minister of Canada does so very well. In Forums like this one in every corner of the country - to listen and to account. In a direct, unfiltered and face-to-face fashion. And tonight, it  »s in the city of Saskatoon. So you  »re all welcome, thank you for coming, thank you for what you will contribute to this dialogue, ladies and gentlemen, Justin Trudeau.

Thank you thank you Saskatoon. Thank you Ralph for your warm words, thank you President for welcoming us here, thank you for the welcome on traditional Treaty 6 territory, it  »s a real pleasure to be here. Please, sit down, we  »re all friends here. I  »m really pleased here, this is a great turnout. This shows that - and there  »s an overflow room down the hall as well. It really shows that people are interested in engaging in the political process. In being part of coming out this evening and talking with the Prime Minister, asking questions, sharing some of the things that are important to you that you think about, figuring out where we are going as a country, talking about how we can each of us, as citizens, play a role in participating in building a better future for ourselves, for our kids, for our grandkids.  That  »s very much what I  »ve been doing over the last weeks over the country - I think this will be my 9th town hall, and it  »s been great. We  »ve had a huge range of questions on mental health - and of course we need to talk about that today because it  »s Let  »s Talk day, and if we haven  »t retweeted that and shared storied about struggles of mental health we need to, questions about veteran. I think we needed to have a day of experiencing what Toronto had to offer, they went to a couple of Raptors games and a rally jam-packed couple of days. I got to sit down with them and talk with them, including Jeremiah who asked me to give a shout out to this girl he knew Shay-lee, which is something that I was glad to do that night I had the town hall in London. A little reminder that kids are kids wherever they are. And regardless of the tragedies and the difficulties that people are facing we need to make sure that we are allowing kids to remain kids. And giving them the experiences and the hope and the opportunities that we need to have across the country. We have big challenges across this country on a broad range of issues. But one of the things that constantly reminds me of why we do this and encourages me to think that we are going to be able to work together successfully to build the best possible future for ourselves, our communities, our kids, is our capacity to roll up our sleeves and tackle these problems together. And that  »s why I  »m so pleased to be here tonight and to hear from all of you, and to chat with you on some of the issues you  »re facing, and mostly to keep working hard every day for you and for this country. So thank you very much for being here tonight and I  »m looking forward to getting to your questions. Yes. Let  »s start with a question from this section. Yes, you sir.

Good evening Mr. Prime Minister, thanks for coming. The question that I have for you actually it  »s related to the carbon tax policy. Of course, this being Saskatchewan I  »m sure you saw this coming. The question I have for you is what is the, what is the strategy behind choosing to pursue carbon tax, when there is ample evidence on the record in other jurisdictions showing that that policy hasn  »t worked. Why are we not pursuing a made in Canada strategy to combat climate change.

That  »s a great question. And it  »s an important one, because we know that one of the things we have to make sure we  »re doing is creating jobs, protecting jobs, building opportunities for Canadians to have good work today, tomorrow, in the years to come. And that  »s exactly why we  »ve chosen to move forward in a way that protects the economy and protects the environment. You talk about a made in Canada strategy, well the fact is, we have a made in Canada strategy. A strategy that draws on the tremendous success that British Columbia has had at pricing carbon, and making sure that putting a price on carbon polluters, their economy is more innovative and they get more solutions and are creating jobs of tomorrow. But more than that, what we  »ve managed to do coming together, creating a pan-Canadian framework on climate change that allows all provinces to do different things in different ways, to respond to their needs and their concerns, and will reduce our carbon emissions. And a part of that is recognizing the challenge of climate change, and part of that is also recognizing the opportunities that come with climate change. It  »s not a debate any more. Climate change is real. It  »s showing its impacts across the country, we know it  »s going to get worse. It  »s going to be more challenging. More floods, more droughts, more changes in weather patterns, more need to adapt, to mitigate the damage. So the question always is, how do we prepare for that. How do we make sure that yes we have good jobs today, but we  »re also bracing ourselves to manage the challenges come tomorrow, and take advantage of the opportunities that are coming with it. Putting a price on things that we don  »t want, like carbon pollution, is a way of encouraging people to innovate and figure out how to get around it. But I  »ve heard you. This transition period as we figure out a way to thrive on an economy that is less reliant on carbon is going to be tough on certain people. And that  »s why part of our proposal on pricing carbon pollution, the core of it is a promise that any money collected in Saskatchewan will stay in Saskatchewan. Anything anyone here pays in terms of a price on carbon pollution is money that the Premier, not the Federal Government will determine how to get back to the people who need it in Saskatchewan.  And what that will do, in terms of supporting people through this transition, is to make us think, because it encourages us to think about ways to pollute less, to innovate more. To think about where the jobs of tomorrow are going to come while doing it today. Now the previous government talked a big game about growing the economy. But they weren  »t able, for example, to create pipelines for example that are needed to develop, responsibly, our fossil fuels industry. And I say develop responsibly because we know we do have to figure out how to be less reliant on fossil fuels. But that  »s going to take significant amounts of time. And in the meantime, we have to make sure that the jobs, that the economies that are, right now, reliant on our fossil fuels  industry, get incentives to be better at using technology, to emit less, be more efficient, to become leaders at developing technologies that the world is going to need. And the way we do this, the way we decide that, you know what, we  »re going to put forward leadership on climate change, and meet our Paris Commitments, we  »re going to support people who need help with this transition, we  »re going to put a price on carbon, and doing that will allow us to do something that the previous government wasn  »t able to do, which is actually get pipelines like the Line 3 pipeline built. That  »s the balance we have. And that  »s what we have to try and manage. Now anytime you  »re going to make a decision, particularly around pipelines, you  »re going to have people unhappy with that decision. It  »s a big decision - there will be some people who will say   ìnope, you should have approved all pipelines  ù, there are other people who will say   ì no, no, no, you should approve no pipelines  ù and we did approve two. Looks like Keystone XL might be happening as well. So moving forward in a thoughtful, responsible way, that understands we do have to shift and grow our economies to adapt to the new reality of climate change, the challenges and the opportunities that come with it, in a way that doesn  »t hurt the most vulnerable, that protects the jobs we have today, that encourages people to think about the cleaner greener jobs that we know are going to come as we work on it tomorrow. It won  »t happen fast enough for some, it  »ll happen too fast for others. But I  »m confident that listening to Canadians, working with good people from coast to coast to coast, we  »ve got that balance right. Thank you very much for your question. A question from the back. You sir, in the glasses.

Thank you so much for this evening Mr. Prime Minister, I  »m an international student here from Iran, I was wondering if you could tell us about your future plans for resuming political ties with my country. As you may know the Canadian embassy in Tehran is closed now, and my friends and I we face many hardships to go to neighboring countries to apply for our Canadian visa, and also, our parents have to face these hardships to get a Canadian visa.

Thank you for the question. I think  _ and welcome here, and thank you for choosing to study here in Saskatchewan. Yes there are many different ways of looking at international relations and how Canada should engage with the world. But I  »m of the opinion that engaging in conversations, even with people you disagree with, is better than not talking to people you disagree with. Indeed, in diplomacy, it  »s more important to have conversations with people you disagree with than just conversations with people you agree with. However, we continue to have significant concerns with the Iranian government, which means we are cautiously reestablishing relations, in a way that doesn  »t ease off on the serious concerns we have about human rights internally, state sponsorship of terrorism, concern around the nuclear ambitions that have been expressed in the past, and carefully monitoring the agreement that was signed. Being thoughtful about how we engage, because right now anyone needing Canadian consular services in Iran has to go through Italy. And when we had the situation of Dr. Homobutfar from Concordia who was emprisoned in Iran for talking about, for doing research on feminism, for example, it was work that we did with the Italians, with the Swiss, and the Iranian government to try to get her home and we were successful in that. And part of that success was showing that we weren  »t unwilling to engage at all with the Iranian government, but that we were ready to talk with them about certain issues and certain files. But we do have to be very thoughtful, and responsible in how we approach, but one of the things that I always do is make a very clear distinction between the Iranian people and the Iranian government. I think that there are a lot of people in Iran who have questions and challenges around their governments and I think having engagement, diplomatically, to certain levels is ultimately good for them. Question, yes, you in the back.

Thank you so much for taking my question. My question is in regards to bill F-217, commonly known as Win  »s law. I  »m sure you  »re aware that unfortunately two years ago constable David Win was shot and killed at St. Albert. Since then, Michael Cooper has brought this bill forward to help change the law that states that currently,  the prosecutor or the police service may provide information on past criminal history currently that that person at the bail hearing is charged with. This bill has been passed unanimously twice in your House of Commons. And on the third reading, the Minister of Justice declined the bill. My question to you is, Mr. Prime Minister, is why have we not been given an explanation as to why the government would support this Minister of Justice in declining such an important bill that could improve the safety of Canadians. Not only just our police officers, but also the general public. Making this information mandatory to be presented to the Justice of the Peace or judge granting the bail, is quite important so why would we not make that mandatory? Any how can we ask these people granting bail to criminals, how can we ask them to make that choice without granting that information that is quite important for them to make a decision that is already in our law, that states that people are only granted law should they deserve it, and how can they make that choice if they are not presented with the right information. So could you please explain to me why we have not had explanation on why she would unilaterally to decline this bill after it  »s been unanimously passed twice. And, if I may ask, please, I  »m sorry, I  »m getting long winded, but could I also ask for you to reconsider your position on this bill because it is just such a small change that the government would make, just a word, that would have a significant difference in the safety of all Canadians.

First of all, thank you. Thank you for what is obviously a very important issue, to you and to a number of people. The fact is, you have me at a bit of a disadvantage, you obviously know a lot more detail about this particular piece of legislation than I do. I have an excellent cabinet, and an excellent Justice Minister who has my entire confidence and how understands how importance it is to keep Canadians safe, to protect Canadians, while upholding our charter or rights and freedoms. And that is something that we always have to work in balancing. We have to make sure that we know that what Canadian expect is to be kept safe and that their rights be protected. Getting that balance is sometimes a challenge, sometimes counterintuitive, I found myself defending the rights of a convicted terrorist to keep their Canadian citizenship on stage in the last election. In a debate. Think that something like that should be as black and white as:   ìif you  »re convicted of a terrorist offense against Canada, you should be stripped of your citizenship  ù. That seems like something that is obvious, that everyone should able to agree with. The problem, unfortunately, in that, is in the details. Because you can  »t actually strip any Canadian from their citizenship, you can only strip first or second generation Canadians, who have come here from somewhere else. And what that does is it creates two types of consequences, for people that are supposed to be equal. Canadians are not supposed to have different degrees of citizenship, whether they are born here, or whether they live here. But that  »s and example of something that seems to be obvious but that is actually more complex. So without going into the details on that particular piece of legislation, let me tell you, that we are constantly weighing the importance of protecting Canadians  » rights and keeping Canadians safe, particularly the men and women who serve in emergency services, as first responders and as police officers. And that  »s something that I will commit to you to take back to the Minister of Justice and ask her to explain more clearly to you and to Canadians the rationale behind that decision. Thank you very much. Sorry there are a lot of people with questions here and I am going to keep going through. You sir, standing there waiving at me. Yes.

Thank you Mr. Prime Minister, I  »d like to say that I was a man when your dad was Prime Minister. And I watched him do a lot of of, you know, fantastic things, and the one thing is related to First Nations Treaty Rights here in Saskatchewan. I come from treaty land, and I know we  »re celebrating 150 years of Canada this year, it  »s been 110 years since part of our treaty land was taken in 1907. I was told about that in 1973 when I was in grade 10, by one of my grandparents. He said we were going to settle it real soon. It wasn  »t until 1996 when I was working on the land claim, doing some research, that we finally got it. Still in 1999, I was the chief of the reserve, and I went and argued before your commission for the return of our lands from 1907. And they agreed with our argument, when we said that Canada owes us the land. They rethought the decision when they said that Canada doesn  »t owe us any land. Go to a second inquiry. The second one says that they don  »t owe us anything. But I think you do. In 1899, there was a Member of Parliament that said, that if it came down to the interests of the white people and the interests of the native people, the interests of the white people would prevail. So I  »m asking you, we don  »t have to go through anymore hearings, we  »ve had all the hearings, we  »ve had all the judges and the people looking at those things. And making decisions already. You can take it back to your parliament and right that historic wrong to Cowasis. That means that. And I  »ve heard you talk about young people, young first nations particular. I have many children, I have many many grandchildren. And from 1973 until 1996, the investments of those lands didn  »t go to that generation. We lost that generation. We have gangs here. And so, if you don  »t live up to the obligations and return the 1973 land to the Cowasis, we lose another generation. And so I  »m asking you, can you bring it back to parliament? And bring our land claim back to parliament?  And return those lands that belong to Cowasis by treaty. Thank you.

Thank you. Canada has not lived up to the spirit and intent of the original treaty relationships. We have failed to keep our word, the promise of shared stewardship of the land, of partnership, of support, of respect, of walking together, and we  »ve failed in so many different ways. Through residential schools, policies of assimilation, lack of trust and respect and partnership, and we have an awful lot to fix. But one of the things that I am so deeply encouraged by is that in the last election, and over the past years, non-indigenous Canadians have started to speak clearly that this is something that needs to happen. Indigenous Canadians have been clear that reconciliation is essential, and now you have a government that is committed to working side-by-side with you, with indigenous peoples across the country, to fix problems which, as you point out, in many cases go back hundreds of years. It  »s going to be a long process. There are complicated issues to sort out, there are fundamental injustices that continue that you can  »t just snap your fingers or slap down a pile of money trying to fix issues, like ensuring that young indigenous Canadians have the same equality of education, the same equality of opportunity, employment prospects as non-indigenous students, that health services, mental health services, addiction services be available for people right across the country.  That we can demonstrate the kind of infrastructure that will put an end to the boil-water advisories. Create better access to communication, to physical roads, that are all-weather roads that allow access to these communities. We have started in a significant way, on multiple fronts. We have invested real money - 8.4 billon dollars over 5 years in budget 2016, to start closing the gaps that exist in services and education and many things for indigenous Canadians. We have worked on accelerating the treaty resolution processes, on extending claims. And I know that the Minister of Indigenous Affairs Carolyn Bennett is working very hard on a broad range of them, including on your issue, sir. There is much to do, but I am every day encouraged by the level to which Canadians - indigenous and non-indigenous - are focussed on fixing past wrongs, mostly building a future of opportunity, respect and true partnership on this land that we share. So I will bring back your concerns and make sure that we are working on them. Thank you very much. Question from down here in the front now. You sir
Mr Prime Minister thank you for coming to Saskatchewan

Thank you Prime Minister, my name is James Yiu. So a few days ago, Donald Trumps  » chief economic advisor stated that the renegotiation of Nafta shouldn  »t be a concern for Canada. The question, is Canada in a good position to renegotiate and also what does Canada want in return. Thank you.

Excellent question. Let  »s start with what Canadians expect of their Prime Minister in regards to working with the United States. I  »ve heard very very clearly in coffee shops across the country  in the past few weeks, and town halls, that Canadians want several things from their Prime Minister. They want our government to have a constructive working relationship with the new administration in the United States, it  »s going to allow us to work together on issues of shared economic interest, on the trade relationship and millions of jobs on both sides of the border depend on this relationship is part of it, and they expect us to stay true to the values and principles that make us proud to be Canadian. To understand that diversity is a source of strength. That openness to the world is a good thing. For our economy, for our jobs, and for our communities. That we don  »t have to compromise on security to welcome in Syrian refugees. So those two drives, of a constructive working relationship while staying true to our values, is what we are focussed on as a country. So over the past few weeks, we  »ve been, I  »ve had our embassador and senior officials engaging with the incoming administration, to do one thing first of all, which is to establish very very clearly, the level which the success of millions of American jobs depends on a smooth flow of goods and services across our border. Emphasizing the fact that 35 of the American states have Canada as their number 1 export partner. And that on a broad range of issues - from labor rights to environmental rights, to living wages and opportunities for people, Canada and the US are very well aligned. These conversations have gone well. But. These are negotiations, and we  »ll see where they take us. But there is no question that it is very clear that the success of the economies on both sides of our border depend on strong working relationships and smooth flow of goods back and forth. We  »re going to discuss and work with the new administration on a broad range of issues, and we will continue to defend Canadian jobs and Canadian principles. And that  »s what we want. What do we want? We don  »t just want prosperity for Canada. We want prosperity for North America and opportunity for people around the world. Because we know that prosperity an be shared, that good jobs created here at home, and opportunities around the world make the world a better place. So it is with that lens, that, absolutely, we want to help Mr. Trump ensure good jobs for Americans, and one of the best ways to do that is to work well with Canadians while ensuring good jobs with Canadians at the same time. That  »s the kind of approach that we  »re taking, any change in administration brings with it challenges and opportunities, and we are working very very hard to minimize the challenges and maximize the opportunities. Question from the very back. Back row, you standing up.

Can you hear me? So my question is about International Development. The lack of an international development institution, we are well behind the other G7 countries in budget for ODA, as a percent of the budget, and the ODA budget has flatlined in recent years. My question is, in 2017, will you predictably increase the budget in ODA, Overseas Development Assistance, sorry, and what else will you do to increase the role of Canada internationally.

Great question. Thank you for your concern and your interest in how Canada can help around the world. A lot of people end up asking questions, look, we have real challenges we  »re facing here in Canada - marginalized vulnerable communities that need help, challenges around housing, challenges around addiction, challenges around a broad range of issues. Shouldn  »t we be focussing all of our efforts on helping Canadians before we turn around and help people around the world? And of course, we have to make sure we do what we can and everything we can to help Canadians. But we also have to know that the world has gotten to be a very small place. And things that happen overseas have direct impacts on us. One of the best ways to protect - not just Canadian security in a physical sense, but protect Canadian economic opportunities, security and stability, is by playing a positive role in the world. Helping kids in Sub-Saharan Africa have clean water and good schools. Helping rebuild parts of the world that have been devastated by floods and extreme weather events. Understanding that building capacity and opportunity for young people in far-off villages to access the Internet, education, to become participants in an increasingly knowledge based global economy, is ultimately going to be a guarantor of security, of opportunity for Canadians as well. So that  »s why Overseas Development Assistance is important. At the same time, we have to recognize that there have been billions upon billions upon billions of dollars, flowing from Western economies into the developing world, some has made an extremely positive difference, other investments haven  »t moved the dial very much. And we have to be very very thoughtful about the difference between giving someone fish and teaching someone to fish. We need to make sure that our investments are focused on empowering the most vulnerable in meaningful ways, which means doing more for women and girls in communities around the world. Creating opportunities for vulnerable and marginalized communities to become more successful, to become more empowered. We are going to be continuing to invest in predictable ways in Overseas Development Assistance, we  »re going to be smart about how we leverage private funds and convene nations to work together. And a great example of that is what we did with the Global Fund in the fall of 2016. Where Canada pulled together a broad array of nations, and raised close to 13 billion dollars to eradicate tuberculosis, malaria, and AIDS, by 2030. This is a global effort that Canada is playing a leadership role in. There  »s always going to be more needs and more need for more money. Canada is going to be part of the solution, but we  »re always going to be responsible in how we balance our engagement overseas and leveraging that as best we can, with the very real responsibilities we have with Canadians who are vulnerable, who need help through tough times here at home. There will never be enough money to do everything we want to do on all aspects, it  »s about choices, it  »s about priorities, it  »s about making our dollars go as far as we possibly can, and that  »s very much what we  »re focused on.

Hi there, hello Mr. Prime Minister. As an education student, I just want to know if you miss your classroom at all. Do you think that our current standardized education system is the best way for our students to learn, or are you planning on anything to change our current education system?

It  »s a very tempting question for a former teacher, I  »ll  tell you. But I will start by pointing out that I very much respect the Canadian constitution that says education is a provincial responsibility from K to 12. And the federal government needs to play a thoughtful and supportive role in that, and I certainly intend to.  It  »s up to the provinces to deliver education, but I certainly know that the way we look at education, the way we look at skills training, the way we look at secondary education needs to keep up with the times. We  »re in a rapidly evolving workplace, we  »re in a rapidly evolving world that is facing a broad range of new challenges.  And we have to give our citizens the tools to cope with that, and to thrive within a shifting situation. And that means training programs for people that are finding their industries transforming faster than they can adapt. We need to be able to give people new skills. Around technology, around computers, around new, innovative ways of working that  »s going to draw on our minds and our skills and our abilities. We need to make sure that young people in universities have access to top quality post-secondary education. Have access to being able to afford it, to being able to chose to go longer through education, which means, for example, what we  »ve done is guarantee  that you don  »t have to start paying back your student debts until you are making at least 25,000 USD a year. That  »s something that  »s going to make a significant difference in people choosing to follow through on their education. We  »ve changed from tax credits, which you pick up at the end of the year, to upfront grants that we  »ve increased by 50% for low income students, to be able to access the post-secondary education we need. And on the K to 12 area, we  »re working with the provinces to encourage teaching coding at a young age. So that young people can start to understand that regardless of their career, being powerful users of computers, of technology, being knowledgeable users of how to program algorithms, how to think, and help machines and computers do part of the work and the jobs that we  »re going to have - is going to be essential to our success as a country. So, I  »m a deep believer in education, but I know that education need to change to give more flexibility, more opportunity, more awareness to the world and the new challenges that are coming at us extremely quickly, and in an extremely challenging way. I have tremendous faiths in Canadians. And our ability to face-down and overcome the many obstacles w're facing. I also know that as a society, as a country, we need to be investing in giving people the tools they need to succeed -  education, training, developing new skills is going to be an essential part of that. And being innovative and creative in the way that we deliver those skills is going to be a hugely important part of that success. Thank you for your question. A question from down here now. You.

Good evening. My question is about the case processing center in central Alberta, I don  »t know if you  »re familiar, but it  »s moving to Edmonton. The community is quite concerned because 10% of the community is employed there. Can you speak a little bit to the reason why it was moved to Edmonton and if anything will be done to help the community to deal with that?

Yes. This is a decision that the immigration minister took based on evidence, based on the needs of our responsibilities of providing government services in a responsible way. There is no question that this is a difficult decision for the people that work at the center in Vagerville, which is why there was, I know, an offer that anyone that wanted to keep their job and do it in Edmonton would be able to, those who didn  »t would be offered a compensation, a package. But any time there are shifts like this, it can be very very difficult in a community. And I  »m sorry about that, I  »m aware of how difficult it is. I myself went through Vagerville a number of years ago while I was campaigning for the leadership, so I know what a strong community it is, and it  »s one of those decisions that one has to make in government that is a difficult one. We have a responsibility to deliver the programs and services Canadians expect, at a value level for the contributors who actually fund our government - our taxpayers. And making that balance right, making that work as best we can is what we  »re focussing on. But in this case I know how difficult it is for people in that community, I know we are also dedicated to help ease the transition in the community, and look for ways to minimize the very real impacts on the community. Thank you.

No no. Just one line on the one page is that no relationship is more important to me than in Canada than the one with indigenous peoples. That  »s part of a mandate that was given to all Ministers. And I think from our side, the Saskatoon Tribal Council, my question for you is that obviously you think this is an important relationship, but obviously Canada itself doesn  »t think it  »s an important relationship because it hasn  »t shown it yet. And I think that there is a disconnect between what you said, and how your administration, particularly Indigenous Affairs has taken that relationship. We see that disconnect in many ways, but a good example is the 8.4 billion that has been promised, not a lot has reached our communities yet. And especially in areas of education. And I know that people think, wrongly, that we  »re getting all this money. But we haven  »t seen anything yet and I think that that  »s where we want to make sure that people understand that. I know that you  »ve cultivated some relationships with the National Organizations and that  »s important. But those aren  »t Nations. And for us, the individual First Nations are the ones that are the treaty holders, they are the ones with the constitutional rights, and that  »s where yourself and your ministers need to be meeting with those. And we  »ve had meetings with ministers, they have lasted 5 minutes. And that  »s not a relationship. And my question to you is, as committed to this relationship, how are you going to fulfill this important relationship, and ensure deliverology.

Listen, you  »re absolutely right, that this relationship is of fundamental importance to me and to Canada. Making sure that we have true reconciliation, true partnership, with indigenous peoples is essential for how we move forward. And we know that the damages have been great over the past decades, generations and centuries, and there is much to do. But because of our actions, over the last year, there are about 2000 kids who started up the school year, in September, in a brand new school, across the country, in indigenous communities. 16 long-terms boil water advisories were ended, with a lot more going to be lifted in the coming years. And we  »re going to reach our target of ending boil water advisories across the country in 5 years. We have made significant strides forward on investing in indigenous education, 2.6 billion dollars.  And these are things that, yes, are not happening as fast as everyone would like. I  »m impatient as well on getting this done. But we also know we have to get it done right. In partnership. We have to build capacity. We have to make sure that we are truly empowering young people. We have to make sure that we are truly listening and giving weight to the elders. And to the young people, who have clear visions of how they want opportunities. You know I  »ve spoken to a number of chiefs who said, yeah we need a youth center. You want to talk to young people, we need a youth center in our community. Okay, well what would you want in that youth center? Well you know, we need TVs and lounges and sofas so they can hang around. And when a Chief says that to me I pretty much know they haven  »t talked to their young people. Because most of the young people I  »ve talked to are asking for a place to store their canoes and paddles so they can connect back out on the land, and a place with Internet access so they can do their homework in a meaningful way, because their homes are often too crowded and they need a place to work and study. We need to make sure we are listening to indigenous voices, because this is not just about throwing money at the problem. Although yes, we  »ve got a lot of investments going, it  »s also about demonstrating real progress on issues that have gone on far too long. And that  »s going to take new ways of approaching these challenges. It  »s going to take learning on both sides. On the government side, and on the indigenous side. As we figure out how to get this right. Because as we said, Canadians are here with us on this. They want - non-indigenous Canadians want to see us repair this relationship and move forward in shared prosperity and opportunity. This is a chance like we  »ve never had before. Where the good will on all sides is there. We have to do it right. This is a tremendous responsibility to yes, give the emergency supports and the mental health crisis supports we need right now for kids that are going through terrible, difficult times, for communities that are suffering and struggling right now. But we also have to be building for the long term. We also have to be preventing the cycles that have been set up because of the lost generations due to residential schools. We have to get this right, we have to do it together, and that means being thoughtful and responsible about how we move together. That  »s what Canadians expect, that  »s what indigenous peoples I  »ve met with expect, that  »s what I expect of our government. We will work together. We will change this, for the better, but it  »s going to take years, it  »s going to take decades in some cases. Before we have reversed centuries of mistreatment. Thank you for your leadership and I look forward to continuing to working with you. You sir.

Well thank you Prime Minister. This evening, I don  »t really have a question for you. I simply wanted to say I  »m really grateful for you coming out here, I have a great deal of respect for you to just come out here and take live questions. I wanted to let you know that myself, my wife, my family, my community, we  »re all praying for you. For you, as you guide this country, for your family, as you still are the leader of that too. So thank you.1

Thank you. I appreciate that very much. I was raised by a father who was very Catholic in the old-school Quebec way, we went to Church just about every Sunday, said my prayers every night as a family, read the bible every Sunday evening, and my faith is an important part of who I am. And knowing that there are folks out there praying for me is really important to me. This isn  »t always the easiest job. But I do know an awful lot of politicians, and every single one I know  truly believes, whether they are religious or not, believes that the calling of service, of trying to do right by your community, trying to build a better future, is one that we constantly have to rededicate ourselves to. And whether it is meeting community members here, or hearing from you today, I thank you for reminding me of the importance of what it is we  »re working on hard together to build a better world and a better future for all of us. Thank you very much. And, which section haven  »t I dealt with? You, yes yes. I think you get the last question of the night, too, because we  »ve been going a while.

Hi, thank you so much Mr. Prime Minister for coming here today. You mentioned at the beginning of your opening that today is Bell Let  »s Talk Day, and mental health issues are very close to me personally and my family, and I  »m sure they  »re close to many of us in the room today. And so my question to you is what can the federal government do further mental health initiatives, not withstanding the fact that health care falls under provincial jurisdiction?

Listen that  »s great question, and first of all, thank you for standing up. You know it shouldn  »t require any courage to stand up and ask a question like that, but I know that unfortunately still, these days it does. There  »s still a stigma around health issues, and too many people don  »t talk about them out loud. And I  »m incredibly proud today that I got to exchange a Tweet with Clara Hughes, who has demonstrated her courage and bravery in sharing her own struggles with mental health issues and sharing and inspiring Canadians to shift their approach. I  »m incredibly proud of my mom, who has been sharing her lifelong struggles with mental health. Which, when you think about it the statistics say one in five Canadians struggle with mental health issues, which means five in five Canadians know someone who struggles with mental health issues. Whether friends, or family, or co11lleagues, workmates. So we need to do a lot more about supporting resilient, supportive communities, addressing the fact that this issue has a massive cost on individuals, on families, on communities, and on jobs and our economy as well. Which is why one of the things that we  »ve done as a federal government is recognize the need for real action on mental health, and we  »ve committed a historic unprecedented 5 billion dollars on mental health specifically. And I  »m very proud to say that Saskatchewan, and Bradwall is one of the seven Premiers that have signed on to this approach in meaningful ways. This is something that we can agree on, that all Canadians know we have to move forward in thoughtful, responsible ways on. And one of the things that we are very interested and indeed excited about  is the fact that research has shown that for most people who have faced mental health challenges, some of their first occurrences, their first symptoms, happen when they are young people. So one of the goals that we have is to try to make sure that young people have much better access to mental health support. Timely, easy, free access to the kinds of support that they need when the go through difficult moments. This is a day when we need to talk about that. This is a day when we need to be understanding of how being strong, compassionate, resilient as a country is essential to our success, and is exactly what we intend to do in the coming years. I thank you all for your questions, it  »s a pleasure to be here, it  »s great to be back in Saskatoon, Thank you for participating in this open Town Hall, thank you for all your questions, I look forward to seeing you all again soon. Merci beaucoup tout le monde.

I would like to answer your question Bill Morneau posed to an audience member in response to her concerns for the not-for-profit sector about how the government can further help.

Since increased regulation of the not-for-profit sector in the mid-90s, government grants have been largely project based - which is also common of grants given by the private sector. Additionally, we know it is easier to get donations from private individuals for tangible items or projects. In essence, if you have a short-term, definable project - you can get it funded by the public sector, the private sector or by individual philanthropists. But nobody wants to fund operational costs. Nobody will turn on your lights or pay non-contractual salaries. And what further compounds this problem is not only can you only fund short-term projects, they very often have to be brand new projects you have never tried before. If you've done a project before, they're somehow now considered part of your regular operations. This is a terrible model that causes not-for-profits to go back to the drawing table, year over year, to dream up new short-term projects because last year's perfectly viable program is un-fundable. The turnover rate of projects caused by this model necessitates extra staff time to a) dream up new projects, b) write brand new grant applications, c) train staff on the new project, d) work out the kinks of the new project. We know regulation of the not-for-profit sector is not going away, but they do deserve more recognition - by way of operational funds. Operational funds would additionally reduce staff turnover rates, making the not-for-profit sector more effective.Not-for-profits across Canada play essential roles in our communities and as our society as a whole. It's time for the government to reconsider how the not-for-profit sector is treated. Consider the possibility of matching funds - for every dollar given to a not-for-profit by the private sector or philanthropist for a short-term project, the government should donate a dollar towards operational funds or long-term projects.

Hi everyone, My name is Andr_ Brisebois and I work at LPC's National Office. My job is to support members' work in the policy development process. This new page is designed to help Liberals discuss the Constitutional amendments above prior to the June 18 extraordinary convention. I'm here to answer your questions and ensure a smooth process. With that said, let's get the discussion going! The floor is yours

HI I fully support delaying the Leadership Convention as stated. I believe that Bob Rae and the party Directors need more time to rebuild the party in an effort to make it more in tune with the needs of the electorate. I am unable to attend the June 18th event as a delegate. but those are my thoughts. Aline Revoy

Does anyone have an idea of what would happen if the amendments to the constitution are not passed? What would be the political and financial impact of not approving them? I'm not necessarily opposed to the amendments, but just want full disclosure as to what would happen to the party if they didn't pass. Thanks!

I also agree with postponing the Biennial Convention and leadership vote until at least the dates specified in the ammendment. I'm sure all our members agree that our party needs to evaluate our future policies and determine the needs of Canadians after the Conservatives and NDP get thier first couple of years in power. I wouldn't want the party making rash decisions until the dust settles. Just look south of the border to see how peoples values change in a short period of time. Our party always stood up for Canadians so I think we just need a liitle time to sort out things. I am unable to attend on June 18 but would support the ammendment posted in this website.

@F.Andrews: good question! Re: the 1st amendment, if it doesn t pass it means that we will follow the Constitution as it stands and will immediately be in a Leadership race leading up to October 2011, at which time there will be a Leadership Vote (One member, One vote). Furthermore, Leadership races do not have much incentive for Party unity since candidates are battling each other for the top position. As for the financial side, leadership races require much fundraising by the candidates which could possibly be in conflict with the Party s fundraising efforts. I could go on but I think you get the picture. Re: the 2nd amendment, it means that the Party may have to organize a Leadership Vote for October 2011 and a biennial convention for late Fall 2011. While possible, it will be a considerable amount of work in a short period of time. Furthermore, delaying until the new year would mean a new tax year which could be an incentive for the members and donors that have already reached their maximum contribution to the Party.

A Leadership Vote on October 29 2011 is to soon October 2012 is to soon . We have to give Harper and Layton time they will do our work for us, by 2013 , we will have a good idear what kind of leader is needed , time is our friend , rush and we could be 3rd for a long time. George Smith

Hello, I fully support the proposed amendments. I believe the time frames laid out make sense. The Party needs time to regroup and refocus before choosing the right person to lead us in the next elections.

Hi, I think we all need to hear what the Leadership has to say before deciding anything. My instinct is to go with the need for more time, but there must have originally been a good reason for setting the time-line the way it is. I d like to know what we lose by not holding the convention at the normal time. Regards to all from London West. Welwyn Wilton Katz

Hi Welwyn, I ll attempt to answer your question  if by Leadership you mean the Leader of the Party, Bob Rae, I cannot speak for him but he has stated that he wants the position to be more than a  summer job  and members seem to agree that rebuilding the Party will take a certain amount of time. The original reason for setting the current timeline goes back to the Chr_tien-Martin days when Jean Chr_tien announced his  eventual  resignation but took a good amount of time to actually do so. Hence the rule that the Leadership Vote must be held within 5 months after the Leader s announcement of or actual resignation (Constitution 54(2) & (3)(b)). On another note, we must not confuse the term convention  Since now we have one member, one vote for the  Leadership Vote , a convention refers strictly to the biennial convention or an extraordinary convention. As I mentioned earlier, delaying the biennial convention until January will provide us with more time to organize and may provide an incentive to members and donors that have maxed out their contributions to the Party since 2012 will be a new tax year. Finally, if by  Leadership  you mean the National Board of Directors, these resolutions have been proposed by the NBoD following consultations with members and extensive member input (emails, facebook, etc.).

I agree wholly with the comments posted above. I would add that a Leadership Process is necessarily divisive, and the one thing we DO NOT need at this point is disunity. We have had two leaders recently, within a relatively short time, and neither of them had a fair chance to prove themselves or to become known to the electorate outside the party, before an election call. Let us learn from past experience, so that we can give ourselves time to heal, and time to choose a leader who can lead us without the pressure of an impending election campaign. Let s look upon the coming four years as an opportunity and not a disaster. Long Live the Liberal Party of Canada!

I have a couple of general questions. First, there were some serious dirty tricks during the election campaign   fake calls purportedly from Liberal candidates, and later fake ones purportedly from Elections Canada. Does the party have a team in place to make sure that these are fully investigated and prosecuted? I know it can t be our main focus, but we MUST ensure everyone knows that this sort of behaviour has consequences. Second, it s clear that the NDP has, from a policy perspective, merged with the Bloc Quebecois. How can we exploit this to pry the centre-left of the entire rest of the country away from them? Finally, how do we stop the media from using the word  subsidy  to describe the public funding system, and refocus the conversation on  Harper changing the election rules in his own benefit ?

I think it is a good decision if we collectively decide to amend the constitution to enable much more time for the choosing of a leader.I will miss this teleconference as i work that day.It will be very good to see more of us LPC members and supporters become actively involved now to help with the rebuilding process.We can come back stronger than ever and deliver a centerist approach that will again enable the quality of canadian society to reach higher levels,and be that positive truly helpful nation to the world at large.

Hi Phil, 1. Re: dirty tricks and fake calls  Elections Canada is currently investigating this. It s in their hands so that s as much as we know about it for now. 2. This sounds like a good question for liberal members interested in policy! I will leave the many possible answers in members  hands since this will surely come back as we will be rebuilding. 3. We cannot control the media nor the spin they put on their stories. All political parties have to deal with this reality. However, I am inclined to suggest that you write a letter to some papers outlining your point of view.

Good morning, I am unable to participate in the extraordinary convention on June 18, however, I feel very strongly that the election of a new leader should be delayed. The Party needs to be more than a leader, and I fear that the fundamentals that built the party into Canada s Party for so many years have been buried. We need to rebuild that foundation, we need to rebuild membership, we need to rebuild the faith in the LPC that Canadians once shared before identifying a leader. We have an excellent Interim Leader, so I see no rush.

Lack of leadership is what got us into this mess. Wandering the political wilderness for two years because our last few leadership choices went poorly is not the way to go. We need to look outside our current stable of MPs and find someone who will rebuild the party in their image _ Bob Rae is a great guy, but he should not be the acclaimed party leader for two years. We need to have a serious discussion about the ideas we stand for, because I can tell you what the Conservatives and the NDP stand for, but not our party. We need to find someone (and quickly) who embodies these ideas and elect them leader. This shouldn t be about how much money they can raise or we ll end up with another  pretty face  who says all the right buzz words but lacks real vision. If you want to merge with the NDP, having the former NDP Premier of Ontario as our leader for an extended period of time is probably the best bet to making that happen. I d support such a merger, but for now it seems that most of the party membership would prefer to remain a separate party. In order to remain separate and avoid oblivion, we need to find out what we stand for.

Hello: My name is Les Gabitous. Unfortunately I will be unable to participate in the extraordinary convention but I support the delay in the leadership election. I would not be upset if it did not take place until the spring of 2013. We need time to rebuild. One of the things we do need to do is become a party where all of our elected members become relevant and not be totally ruled by the Leader and his office. We need to become the party of the people. All members should be heard and not penalized if they do not suport certain platforms put forward by the Leader. Let the Liberals become the party of freedom and representatives of their constituents.

Phil, Just to follow-up on your 1st question as this is a very serious matter, I ve also forwarded your question and comments to info@liberal.ca so that my colleagues are aware of your concern. Rest assure that we are just as concerned as you are and share your feelings.

I fully support the National Board and Council of Presidents in proposing these amendments. As a party we need the time that this solution will give us to allow members, at the January Convention, to set the policy framework for the leadership debate that will follow. It is equally important that party members from all constituencies and commissions participate on June 18th.in order to ensure the legitimacy of the decision and start the rebuilding process. Hopefully the removal of the fear of an immediate election will allow us to have the kind of lively debate that we need to get ourselves back to the point where we are considered to be a serious alternative for electors.

I have read and support the ammendments to the constitution. I cannot participate as a delegate but want to have you count in my oppinion. We need time to re-think, re-align and relate to our grassroots. In my opinion this is one of our failures in recent years. There has been a lack of grassroots involvement in many aspects of the Party and its policies in recent years. The grassroots and Riding activity is how you build and mainatain a Party.

Yes, I also agree the leadership convention should be postponed to give the Party ample time to regroup and rethink its policies. I am definitely not in favor of looking outside the party for a Leader. A case in point is what happened when we did _ ergo Michael Ignatieff. We have plenty of good men and women in the party, bright and capable but if we do look outside the party we should ensure that the person has political experience _ ergo Michael Igantieff. It is not necessary to merge with the NDP and why should we? Are the policies of the NDP policies those that we espouse? There is a huge vacuum that the Liberals can fill so lets be creative and find our own middle ground. We never had difficulty filling that void before this.We will find our own way, we will find issues that are dear to Canadians that are not being fulfilled. Lets keep in mind that 60% of Canadians did not vote for Stephen Harper, no matter what he says (delusional as he is) Within a very short time, Harper and Layton will give us ample issues to oppose. Theres no rush. The Conservatives/Reformers under the present leadership will soon step into another landmine _ and we must be ready to tackle these issues one at a time. And once we tackle them we must not let them drop as we did with the issue of the torture of Afghan detainees. Bob Rae will be a formidable interim leader. He has both the political experience and mental agility to deal with the dullards on the government side. Above all, lets remain united because we have not always been united. Lets think back not too long ago. The canabalization of Stephan Dion, by his own party was as disgraceful as Ive ever seen. This was a good and honest man and what was done to him by the press and the Harperites was bad enough _ but what was done to him by the Party itself was a shame that we will have to live with for a long time. I know of another Liberal who bastardized English and who went on to become one of the most successful leaders of our time. We all remember Jean Chretien. Lets forge ahead, think logically and creatively as well and we will once again rise to become the party that speams for the majority of Canadians. Liberals, the task begins NOW!!

Remember everyone to keep your comments to the 2 resolutions above. There will be other opportunities for discussions on rebuilding and renewing our Party. The process we follow is just as important as its outcomes. We have time on our side so let s do this together one step at a time.

The delaying of the Leadership Convention is a logical and practical course. Firstly, I don t think there is any urgency to rush into a leadership race in our predicament. Secondly, the Liberal Party should spend some more time reflecting on the history of this party, its ideological and pragmatic foundations, and the source of much of its historic electoral successes, Wilfrid Laurier and Pierre Trudeau are names that come to mind. Many believe that the contemporary Liberal Party has shifted to the right, as such, even grassroots members have been having trouble distinguishing the Liberals from the Conservatives. Let us not rush, let us exercise patience and consult more with the grassroots and retired leaders and Canadians in general, whom I believe still have a lot to offer this party. We need to approach politics as true Canadians, we need to convince Canadians we really care about them, and not fighter jets, international military bases and corporate tax cuts.

I disagree with the latest comments of Andre Brisebois. Of course, we need to stick with the resolutions above but please lets put everything in its proper context. And the errors of the past need to be brought into the resolutions being proposed. After losing all but 34 seats, lets be mindful of what led us to that disastrous finish.
Armida raises some very critical and relevant points that we must focus on. However, Andre is also right, for the purpose of this exercise.

First, I support the revisions under discussion. Second, I am available on June 18th, if appointed. Third, comments demonstrate how deeply and differently people see this opportunity. Personally, I believe it is  my  opportunity at the grassroots level to redefine what Liberal means in Canada, and with that definition of purpose and goals, to attract a leader and fellow Canadians that share  my  zeal and commitment to the long term vision that results.  my  of course, means anyone who feels as passionately about the opportunity before us. This is not a game. It is Canada we are talking about, and Canada needs us. If not, let s simply find another leader and put her or him to the torturous test of an election.

I agree that the leadership vote should be delayed   we need to take a serious look at people with leadership potential   and that must be a grassroots based look  . not one imposed on us from on high as was the coronation of Michael. Obviously the Biennial must be postponed until after Dec 31 to allow all those who maxed out the federal party donations in 2011 to attend. From my perspective, the rebuild of the party MUST be grassroots based. Many of the Liberals I speak with are tired of the top down style that we have been getting these last few years and believe that the grassroots must exert control over the party apparatus at both PTA and National level, after all without us, the grassroots, there would be no party.

I agree that we should wait so I support the proposed amendments. We have very little or nothing to gain by proceeding as per our existing constitution. Definitely, time is on our side and will prove that the recent election results were a huge mistake on the part of the electorate. Although not asked of us currently, I would like to voice my opposition to any formal discussion with and/or about the possibilty of merging with the NDP. Jacques Layton and his band of recent college graduates will be back to 3rd party status following the next election. Our guiding principles and history as Canada s natural governing party must be maintained, preparing us to form a majority government by 2019 at the latest.

I also agree that the leadership vote should be delayed. We need time to regroup, rethink/rebrand and fundraise. And I agree with Robert M., the leadership process needs to be grassroots this time _ we need a strong leader that the whole party can support, this isn t the time for anything else! And it s logical from a fundraising perspective to postpone the Biennial convention as well.

What a great set of comments already, from a person who lives in a predominently Conservative region it is nice to hear all the voices of the party. I think it is clear from the posting here and the general feel of the caucus that the leadership vote must be delayed for us to rebuild and it is good so many people feel this way. I think that the best thing to do with all the people out in the field right now is for the Liberal party to reall y step up and be the vioce of so many Caqnadians as it was before. I would hope that those memebers in area with less overall Liberal MPs, such as in the west, reach out to all the communities that they can to build this grasroots movement. If we are belayed with another leadership race this will only serve to, as stated above, divide us when we need to have a unified front and rebuilding process. After all if the foundation is weak and the walls wont hold it, why put a roof over our broken house?

Hi First I agree with the temporary revisions in view of the current situation. However, I hope that these are the opening steps in a war to fight and emerge victorious from coming the 4+-year dictatoship. Hopefully we will still have the currently very angry Quebec in the Country. Its choice of Smiling Jack was just a desperate growl to display their lack affection for Ignatieff, their frustration with the Bloc, and their very strong dislike of Harper; they would have voted for the Yellow Labrador Retriever Party if it had existed. It is now essential to find and nurture a young charismatic Leader better versed in Tweeting to the People in Tim Hortons and who can fiercely, indeed mercilessly,and loudly, hound Harper just as Harper hounded the unfortunate Ignatieff and Dion. It is also first essential for this Leader to wrest Quebec from Smiling Jack if it does not separate under Harper.

Yes I agree to support the proposed constitutional amendments. Following this vote,I hope Liberals will truly focus on rebuilding the party based on realistic timelines and goals that grassroots supporters can be actively involved in. I would also like to see more of these types of forums where Liberals across Canada can interact with each other and share their opinions and ideas on specific topics.

Grassroots, yes. But it s hard to motivate a grassroots movement without ideology that inspires passions. Conservatives have a social agenda that keeps large swaths of their members motivated to donate and participate. The NDP has the socialist/unionist agenda around which the party coalesces. What do we Liberals have to inspire a groundswell of support? Right now, I would argue, not much. In the best case scenario, a leadership race would inspire vigorous debate around exactly such foundational questions. So, let s give ourselves some time _ it seems the best way to ensure that as many new ideas and faces are able to participate in the debate as possible.

I do not agree that we should delay the permanent leadership decision past this October. To me, Bob Rae is not only the savior of the Liberal party, but of Canada. Reading his books I see a man not so filled with hubris that he cannot admit past mistakes. He stands for every Canadian value, and Liberal too, that would make me proud once again to be a Canadian. I think all Liberals should get behind him, and allow him  to do the right thing,  until such time as he decides he has served enough time in public service. I firmly believe that under his leadership more and more Canadians will want to become Liberal. It s not inconceivable, that without any  merger of the left  he will be the next Prime Minister before another election is called.

Defeat can be the greatest of victories. It reminds us of the virtues of humility and grace so necesary in human understanding. Also, it gives us opportunity to re-kindle our vision and formulate an innovative and effective approach to help achieve our common dream for Canada and for the global community. We need time to reach out to fellow Canadians _ Liberals and beyond _ that we may distill from their talents and experiences and thereby fully seize the opportunity that the recent electoral defeat _ painfully disappointing as it is _ has offered to us. I concur with the proposed Amendments. I intend to participate as a delegate. May I add my  thank you  to Michael and my  salute  to Bob.

Good to see there FINALLY is an actual discussion going within the liberal party where members can make comments! (I would suggest adding a tally of thumbs up and down for all comments posted and being able to sort comments appropriately by newest/oldest oldest/newest most thumbs up/down my comments also it would be good to be able to make comments on other comments so they are grouped together .and of course sub-comments rated also ) Questions and comments that come to mind are: - Who is in charge of the party? Is it Bob Rae _ and will he steer the party for the next 2 years as per his point of view? Or is it the National President Alfred Apps? Or is it some committee _ and who is on this committee? Or what? - If we decide to put the convention off for 18+ months _ then what? Do we flounder around until we elect a new leader _ with a power struggle at the top as to who decides course of action for the party to renew itself? - To be honest I don t think the upcoming vote will make any difference if there is no real plan to examine what the liberal party is and what it stands for _ sooner rather than at some point in the future. We need to start at the beginning _ and that would be to look over the Liberal Constitution (79 pages long oppose to all the other parties ~20 page constitution) and update it _ nothing should be off limits from the Preamble (or guiding principles) to the political structure of the party to how we elect the leader to  do we need commissions?  to   - So do we actually have an open/honest/constructive (and in ways destructive) conversation over the next 2 to 3 months about: what the party the Liberals are all about; re-examining our party s constitution; re-evaluate how the party is organize from a leadership/board of directors perspective; and how we can rebuild the party for the next 100 years? After all this introspection then we should decide what course of action is needed including: when we should have a leadership convention; should vote we update the constitution and how; and how should we update the political structure of the party if at all?

I agree and support the proposed amendments. We have 4 years before we go the polls again lets use all the time we need to get our house in order. In no way is the GREAT LIBERAL PARTY dead, just wounded and lets stop the back stabbing and dirty laundry washing in public. Once and for all lets show a UNITED front. lets stop giving lip service to the GRASSROOTS and start listening for a change. I have registered as a delegate for June 18th. Paul Ingram. Past Pres. London-Fanshawe

How can anyone disagree with Philip Chisholm s points on party renewal? This is a party with truly limitless potential for good in a young and underestimated country. Underestimated by ourselves, it s citizens. I believe and from where I sit I see us still shaking off the bindings of a long-defunct colonial power and it s remaining political infrastructure. We are a nation still healing from the damage done, where some continue suffering grave injustices rooted in unchallenged systemic discrimination. Our collective psyches have been affected by these experiences we share. But our party has been the one that fought for whatever equity we do enjoy and crafted the promise of amelioration of inequities. There is a tremendous amount of work to be done, politically, if we are to qualify for the inheritance of the LPC. It is a party with a history that is worth keeping close to our hearts. Going forward, human rights matter to all. Let s build on the past work of the party, in this regard. I agree this is 2011 and we are facing all kinds of beginnings and endings. I come from the food and water security grassroots part of the party. Responding to climate change is demanding we take action sooner than later. We need a food security strategic action plan based on our reality and a platform, ready to go, that literally zings with relevance to the Canadian people. If we delay our leadership race do we delay the building of this platform that will lead and guide the Liberal members who do have seats in the House? We do not want to miss out on the power of repetition. We need a platform that comes out strong in sound bites. For me the important question is how will delaying our leadership race affect our ability to respond to Canadians as the crisis of climate disruption increases and food sources decrease. What about climate change refugees in our own nation? Is is right to pretend that there will not be parts of the nation that are no longer livable? I think Canadians are wanting some rational political party voice to be brave enough, loud enough and stubborn enough (using the power of repetition) to address the gravity of our situation. What have we got to lose? Yet we have everything to gain.

Unfortunately, contrary to initial plans, I will not be available for the  extraordinary convention  on the 18th of this month. However, I would like to say that I agree with most of the previous comments re: holding off on a leadership convention for a period of time my suggestion would be at least two years. As has been stated above, the party needs time to redefine itself in respect to its position in the political landscape of Canada, now that we have the far right and soft right covered, all within the same party, and a centralist position with left leanings also covered with the NDP, whose mandate will have to be clarified in itself respecting the wishes of the numerous ridings that they took in Quebec to replace largely previous Bloc members, yet maintaining a traditional NDP position respecting a range of positions from central to a considerable distance left of centre. The Liberals need to define a traditional centralist role, yet one that will cover off right and left of centre a challenge indeed with the strong representation already doing this with the other parties. With the large youth population in Parliament now, accompanied with those younger people who are now taking an interest in politics, the Liberals need to focus on attracting this part of the population as well as the middle aged and the more senior, cutting across every nationality within our borders. We are so privileged to have such a diversified population in Canada with the wealth of cultures contributing to our mosaic. The Liberal Party must become the party of choice in a political world where they are going to be less visible than the other two mainstream parties. A strong, and I believe, young leader is required and is on equal footing in respect to importance as the redefinition of the mandate of the Party.

Thank you Philip Chisholm for your suggestions, and in particular i will pass along to the web folks your ideas for extra features for this forum. It is a very fair question to ask what the timetable would look like if the Leadership Vote is delayed. After having reviewed all of the suggestions that have poured in from party members, riding presidents, former candidates etc. it is expected that the National Board of Directors will release a proposed national timetable before the June 18th extraordinary convention, which would offer a rebuilding schedule should the Leadership Vote be delayed. Whether posting here, or by contacting the party through info@liberal.ca I encourage everyone to offer their ideas as to how you believe a rebuilding period should be mapped out if the Leadership Vote is delayed to a later date. And just a note about who s in charge of the rebuilding of the party, well, it s you. Three unwavering principles are: join and recruit others to become members of the party, get involved with your riding association (join the executive!) and donate _ both to your riding and the national party. https://action.liberal.ca/en/membership http://www.victoryfund.ca Rob Jamieson National Membership Secretary

Delaying the Leadership Convention seems like a sensible idea. There is no point in rushing into it as so many things need to be considered. Also, I d like the next leader to be able to hold the position for a long time which won t happen if the party isn t rebuilt thoughtfully first. Learning to connect effectively with Canadians again should be the number 1 priority. Also, I think as members we have to realize that our MPs need our help. We can t expect them to do it all on their own while we sit back with our arms crossed waiting to be impressed.

Greetings from Edmonton! I fully support delaying the Leadership Convention as stated. I truly believe that Interim Leader Bob Rae and the Liberal Party of Canada Executive need more time to focus on rebuilding the party to make it more attractive to Canadians from coast to coast to coast. Let s take our time and ensure we have ample time to refocus and rebuild, from the ground up!

Hi, I m Doug Watkins and I wont attend the Conference (I have had a stroke) but I must agree with the Amendments. What I don t see , as I wished, is one that would permit the  Acting pres,  to run (again) as  permanent  pres.

I think these types of open forums are a great idea and I would like to see more of them throughout the Liberal Party website. They allow for candid and intimate conversations to develop and they allow the grass roots of the party to drive the conversation. I hope to see more in the future, especially as we attempt to redefine and renew our great party.

I should add that this is an excellent way to attract me people and ideas; build a sense of community; and generate financial resources. We could turn the Liberal Party website into the  Facebook  of Canadian politics. It s easier to engage a multitude of different people through such initiative than anything else.

I don t think we should completely remove the possibility of Bob Rae becoming the permanent leader should he prove successful. Obviously, we need to encourage new leaders to step forward, which means some conditions must be placed on the position of interim leader, but I think it is premature and foolish to eliminate a potential candidate before he or she has been given an opportunity to prove themselves.

Hi Everyone, Greeting from Mississauga, I fully support delaying the Leadership Convention as stated in the agenda for this extra ordinary convention.   Slow and Steady wins the Race .
