Canada is one of the best countries on this globe built by dynamic immigrants & their generations from different countries & cultures, not to forget the First Nations also who have contributed in making this Great Nation. I believe that Liberal party under the interim leadership of Bob Rae will need more time to rebuild the party in an effort to make it more in tune with the needs of the Canadian people. It is just a matter of time and perseverance which will be successfully accomplished by the reformation of the party s image under the guidance of the new leader work in the best interest of Canada and its people.

Hi all, this comment goes out for anyone who is interested in discussing things other than simply the amendments (eg longer-term renewal). You have a few options: * En Famille (http://enfamille.liberal.ca): this site was actually set up by a grassroots committee within the party in 2008; there are many discussions going on. It s the closest thing to an official discussion forum we have right now. * Facebook: there are several groups (in no particular order: Liberal Renaissance; Liberals Rebuilding the Liberal Party; Canadians Rebuilding the Liberal Party; there may be more) that you can join. Some are more active than others. * Blogs: make sure you watch liblogs.ca and/or liberalsonline.ca. You can discuss right on various blogs, and they ll also point you towards new resources as they pop up. * Twitter: follow the #lpc hashtag.

Rob Jamieson thanks for the response  On one my questions you responded but didn t answer the question: Who is in charge of the party? Is it Bob Rae _ and will he steer the party for the next 2 years as per his point of view? Or is it the National President Alfred Apps? Or is it some committee _ and who is on this committee? Or what? Sure, we can all make comments until we are blue in the face on this Liberal Forum _ but at the end of the day who will reviews all the comments and decides which ones to keep and which one to ignore? Which comments are important and which are irrelevant? What direction will the party take? Who make the final decisions on the direction of the party, on constitutional amendments, on what constitutional amendments are presented for a vote, etc  _ is it a committee or party leader or party president or  all members one-person-one-vote  or??? It is still not clear to me and I think this is a critical question that deserves an answer. Thanks.

Hi. I am standing for election as a delegate. I agree with the proposed amendments. I am a passionate Liberal and have all kinds of comments to make, but respect the need to keep this board focussed on the task at hand. For now can I ask that Liberal members meet over at en Famille s forums, which can be found here http://enfamille.liberal.ca/login.aspx?ReturnUrl=%2flogout.asp If you ve never been before, it may take a couple of days to become authorized. The moderators are volunteers.

We have to remember that there is a lot to learn from the Party past experience. I m referring to the period of 1957-63 when the Liberal Party ended in the situation very similar to the one we are facing today. It took six years for our party to return to power. We have to look back and identify how it was done. There are plenty of documents from this period. Good starting point for all of us would be the book by prof. Joseph Wearing  The L-Shaped Party: The Liberal Party of Canada 1958-1980 .

I thank you for putting this forum together. Great idea. I ve read the comments to date. One common thread appears to be the want for the grassroots to rise up and have their say and in so doing lead the rebuilding of our great party. The trouble I am having with this entire  Special  process is the fact that we are so easily tossing around the articles of our constitution which is the Bible _ so to speak _ of our party. These articles in our constitution were written by grassroots members past and present. Some took years in the making. In fact, the 5 month rule only came after years of hardwork before it became a new article in 2009. Now, at the very first sign of trouble and at the first point in time that this new rule can be utilized, we are going to overide it for the sake of convenience. I m not entirely convinced that we can claim to be rebuilding a party of grassroots leadership when our first order of business in so doing is to trample on the very book that governs us. While I have the floor, I d like to know why the National Executive has not set out the rules and dates for the October 2011 Leadership Vote? Constitutionally, and in spite of this Special Convention, they were bound to set the date by no later than May 30, 2011. Is it arrogance? Is it assumed that the amendments will be passed on June 18 so the heck with following the constitution? Alf Apps himself admitted on the Council of Presidents call that he had to set the October date. Now we are once again in violation of our own good book. This is not how to go about rebuilding.

Nanaimo, BC again I joined the party right after the election. Like so many Canadians I have been leaving it up to  others  to make my democracy work. As this blog indicates, democracy is messy and noisey and passionate. I joined for the right to join  you  and everyone else who senses the challenges we face as Canadians _ not simply Liberals, defeated or otherwise. The only direct contact I ve had since I joined is a boiler-room call to give money. More money is not the problem we face today: that is old think. We have to emerge as being something far more relevant than we have presented before. I joined to participate in the party, not wait for others to simply send me decisions or positions that are still fighting a battle we plainly lost. What attracts me and I believe what will attract Canadians at large, is a wholesale redefinition of what democracy in the 21st Century looks like in a modern, advantage society. As this blog demonstrates, this is our  civic square  and it is here that the process has started. Now I m informed that I should monitor four or five other blogs to find out what liberals are thinking and doing. PLEASE let the party executive harness this wonderful energy and let s get at it and let s start at  home  as well. I cannot find another Liberal to talk to in Nanaimo. Why is that so hard? There is something very exciting and important going on in all of this, and I want to do my part

Hello to all, I have expressed my intention to participate in the extraordinary convention on June 18. Moreover, I support the constitutional amendments that would delay a leadership convention and a biennial convention. I have been a loyal liberal supporter since I first voted in 1993 and on May 3, 2011 I joined the Liberal party of Canada because I want to help rebuild the party that gave so much to me when it governed. I believe the liberal party of Canada needs to rebuild the party from the bottom up. It needs to surround itself with fresh young faces and ideas. Its policies and platform that it will use to get elected and govern must be from the center with compassion, social justice and fiscal responsibility. The most important thing of all is that the Liberal party of Canada must listen to the Canadian people. Once this simple structure and change is established then a leader can be chosen. Regards Peter Papadakis (Laval les-iles, Qc.)

Hi, I intend to stand as a delegate for the upcoming Convention, and I d like to just detail a few of my thoughts here. Firstly, I m a young voter; this past election was the first I ve participated in (I m 20 this summer). As a young voter, I d like to share some insight with regard to how I perceived the election, specifically insofar as the LPC is concerned. My main issue here is that the Liberal Party seems, at the moment, to be not only unfocused, but concerned with seeking some sort of easy way to regain its traditional position as political heavyweight. Michael Ignatieff did a good job. He was not the problem with the recent Liberal showing. The silly accusations I read in the Star mere days after the election (by Liberal MPs, no less!) merely serve to validate the criticisms that other parties levied at us throughout the campaign, namely that we can t seem to agree on anything and that we re overcome by infighting. This detracts from any positive policy oriented message we can come out with. In short, the LPC was complacent this past election. We thought that now that Mr. Ignatieff was in the driver s seat, we wouldn t be plagued by the lame-duck accusations which so doomed Dion. Obviously, Dion wasn t the problem with the party, and neither was Ignatieff. The fundamental issue is a lack of coherent policy. It s not so much about being right, left, or center, but more about having some sort of focus or area of expertise which we concentrate the bulk of our efforts on. The Conservatives picked the economy, and the NDP picked idealistic revolution. What did the Liberals pick? We picked  not Conservative.  Be it health care, be it education, or be it the economy, the LPC needs to pick ONE, and only one, and make that the focus of its platform. That s not to say that we need to speak about only one thing, but something needs to be central. Something needs to be chosen around which all other positions can be anchored. In essence, we need a unity of policy. All that remains is to decide what it will be. I say we go on the basis of Constitutional/Parliamentary reform coupled with a brazenly socialistic approach to services. No dancing around the point or trickily naming things, but coming right out and saying that we intend to take Canada in a direction whereby the least privileged are the focal point of our concern, and wherein we do not pander to corporations or in-circles to win votes. The LPC needs to build for itself an image of integrity again. This isn t just about getting a new leader. It s about finding passion again.

I have registered to be a delegate for the extraordinary convention. There are lots of insightful comments here, but I have a concern about the delay that I don t see addressed. In my opinion, Mr. Rae is a perfect choice as interim leader, but presuming that he will not be the actual leader after a leadership race has taken place, my concern is the  change of command . We don t know what the LPC plans are for this rebuilding and rebranding period. Will it be administrative (which is desperately required) or political or both? And what controls will be in place for the new leader to inherit? Will the new leader continue the interim leader s direction or will we be going off half-cocked again? The longer an interim leader is in place, the more the party will begin to take on his vision and this could cause problems. I am in favour of a delay, but not as long as some others have suggested. My two cents _ leave the politics alone for the first year (as much as possible). Get an organization in place that can issue tax receipts and membership cards, etc. in a timely fashion. Use the first year to streamline the basic administrative functions. Consider removing the commissions. Consider removing the Council of Presidents. Consider removing at least parts of the cumbersome provincial arms. The LPC is so fraught with red tape that this is part of the reason why volunteers on the ground are so frustrated. Simplify, simplify, simplify. Diane McLeod Membership Chair _ Kamloops-Thompson-Cariboo

After forty years of being a Liberal the last month has been a very difficult time. This the the fourth election the Canadian people have rejected our policies. I would bet that many of us feel the same as me. It is certainly a time of reflection for the whole Liberal family. There are are some among us that are likely thinking along the same lines as me. Does the Party represent what I truly want Canada to be in the future or to put it a different light does the Party represent what Canada needs to be in the 21st century. One thing that has become very clear to me is that at this time Canadians do not want NEW national and costly programs. That in itself has struck at the very heart of why I am Liberal. I believe that the majority of Canadians still want a just, caring and properous society. At the same time they have rejected the Liberal way, we must therefore take the time to rebuild. Let Mr. Rae lead the Party for the next two years and that will give us the membership the time to pick the right leader to lead the Party.

Hi my name is Kerry Nelson and I work at the LPC s national office. It s great to see so many passionate Liberals posting comments about the proposed amendments. Many people have posted that they are standing as delegates. Thanks for stepping up! I am helping to organize the convention and I am happy to be here to help answer your questions. @Philip Chisholm: RE:  Who is in charge of the party?  Delegates at the Extraordinary Convention will determine how we move forward by voting for or against the proposed amendments. The decisions of these delegates will have an enormous impact on our organization. If the Constitutional amendment to delay the Leadership Vote does not pass, we will elect a new leader this October _ One Member, One Vote. For your question of  Does Bob Rae lead the party or Alfred Apps?  Of course they both have leadership roles, but neither of these individuals can override the decision of our delegates on June 18th. The National Board of Directors made the decision to propose these amendments to the delegates at the extraordinary convention based on feedback from our members. For Frequently Asked Questions, check out our FAQ page _ http://www.liberal.ca/faqs/ @Dale Partridge: RE: Harnessing your wonderful energy. Yes please! The best way to find meaningful involvement in your riding is to join your local riding executive. When I first joined the Party it took me a few years to realize that my local executive was where my political network would begin. Local ridings organize events, meetings, policy resolutions for the biennial convention ect. It can be frustrating to have so much wonderful energy and not know who to talk to. Here is the information for your local riding presidents: William Stewart is president of Nanaimo Alberni ab.stewart[at]shaw.ca and C. James Wright is president of Nanaimo Cowichan wrightsathome[at]shaw.ca Engaging Liberals on our website is a very exciting change for our organization. I look forward to hearing from you!

Hello from Halifax/Dartmouth! I seem to be following the consensus of the comments here. We certainly should take time to gather our thoughts as Liberals and as a party on the direction and what our philosophy will be moving forward. It seems we have lost our way. I have spoken to many people before the election, during and since liberals and non-liberals. The one thing many people have mentioned is the Liberal Party is not like it once was. When talking to persons who were once liberal and seemed to move away from our party have in common is they believe the party has abandoned them. As a past candidate in provincial politics, it is my opinion we should begin by focusing on including young people as a key component to rebuilding our party along with considering the many other things we need to rebuild. That said, I agree with the delay and the amendments.

Hi, I can only be for the proposed amendment. We have, right now in the party, a need for stability and certainly not to tear us apart. But what I think is that the party have to find an issue in which it is clearly distinct than the other canadian parties. I think the major problem we had during the last electoral campaign is that the liberal party was too alike with the NDP, and altough I  m not opposed to many NDP ideas, I privilege the pragmatism that I see in the Liberal party. But being pragmatic doesn t mean doing nothing and surfing on whathever popular tendencies. We have to have something different to propose to Canadians. I don t know yet what, but I know we need that.

Bob Rae is not the answer although we are grateful to him for acting as an interim leader, but that is as far as he can take us. I agree that the leadership convention should be postponed since first of all we have not had any real leadership candidates emerge. I want a leader who can firstly win an election and be a credible possible Prime Minister. I think thbat during the next year to eighteen months some prospects will emerge. If we do it in October we will be stuck to choose between a group of  losers  who can neither raise the necessary funds to fuel an election campaign, nor can they create any excitement among the grassroots supporters. So many of us have been ignored for so long and it is time to change the party  brass  who have created this situation. I feel it is more important to rebuild the party from the bottom up and then choose a viable leader chosen by the party rather than by the M.P. s as was done in the recent past. If this once great party does not return to democracy and include all the membership we are doomed to repeat the mistakes of the past.

Reading over the amendments (several times and I have read over many legal documents) I have no clue exactly what they mean _ and I would bet most members are confused also. I propose that any amendment be written in plain simple English (rather than lawyer speak) _ and that the proposed amendments are rejected until they are re-written in plain English understandable by all. Call it the clarity proposal is you so wish. And that this would apply to all new amendments. And to stir it up a bit a little brainstorming to get some creative discussions going   . I propose that the roles/hierarchy of all executive positions be discusses and evaluated so members can clearly understand what each position is responsible for and where they fit on the organization chart. And that an online forum, open to all party members, be set up to facilitate open discussion about the role/hierarchy of each executive position. In this discussion I would suggest that we also evaluate the structure of the party, and if needed, to re-design the overall structure of the party so it better reflects today s realities. I propose that the members of the party, in the next 2 to 3 months, examine and question carefully all party leaders/executives and decided if they are the right people to lead the party going forwards. And that an online forum, open to all party members, be set up to facilitate this examination. I propose that in the next 3 to 6 month all executive positions of the party (including the caucus leader, all presidents, all commission executives and any/all other executive position) be open to a vote (by all members of the party _ one person one vote) to decide who will occupy said positions. And that any member of the party can apply to these positions with no restrictions other than being a member of the party. And that an online forum, open to all party members, be set up to facilitate open discussion why the candidate is best suited for the position in question. I propose that all executive positions be reviewed yearly and voted on by all members of the party (online? _ one person one vote) to ensure that the positions are occupied by the best candidate. If confidence is lost in an executive then the position will be open to all members of the party and within 3 months a vote take place to fill that position. And that an online forum, open to all party members, be set up to facilitate open discussion why the new candidate is best suited for the position in question. Not sure if this is the way to proceed to rebuild the party but we must start somewhere and at the beginning the foundation is a good place to start I would think!

Hi Philip, Thanks for your comments! Firstly, I ll do my best to help clarify the resolutions  The 1st one says that the NBoD shall meet, as they are required to do as per section 54(3), on OR before October 1st, 2012. Then, in consultation with the Caucus and the Council of Presidents, the NBoD will set a date for the Leadership Vote between Nov. 1, 2012, and Feb 28, 2013. The Party will be given 5 months notice for the Leadership Vote (as required by the Constitution). The last line just says that this amendment shall no longer be of force or effect once the Leadership Vote hereby discussed has taken place or by February 28, 2013. In other words, it is a one-time resolution just for these specific circumstances. The 2nd resolution asks that the biennial convention take place January 13-15, 2012. It also states that this is a one-time resolution that will no longer be of force or effect once the biennial takes place. The governance issues that you bring up (structure & practices) will certainly be discussed as we will be rebuilding our Party. Just remember: all members who currently hold executive positions in the Party, whether on ridings, commissions, or PTAs, have been elected there by Party members. And these individuals are all volunteers. Also, there may be an issue amongst some members with the fact that Party members in BC get to vote on the executive for NB (for example). But these discussions will have to wait, first things first  for now and with this exercise, we need to know whether or not we are in a Leadership race or if we can initiate the discussions on rebuilding our Party (resolution 1). If the 1st resolution is rejected by members, then we are in fact immediately in a Leadership Race leading up to October 2011. If the 1st resolution is adopted, then the Leadership Vote will take place between the dates mentioned and we will be able to focus our efforts on rebuilding the Party. You seem to have many ideas and much energy to put in rebuilding our Party. That is terrific and just what we need! We will need to have open and honest discussions and debate and brainstorm many new ideas. For now, and from my perspective as an employee of your Party, the question is this: do you want us to focus our efforts in the next few months on organizing a Leadership Vote (rejecting resolution 1) or do you want us to focus our efforts on ensuring members  engagement and facilitating discussions between members to rebuild the Party (adopting resolution 1)? The choice is yours!

HI, I am a new member of the LPC. I volunteered to run a campaign office for our local candidate because I was so concerned about the way the Harper as PM had abused the democratic process. As an outsider I can concur that many feel that the Liberal Party does not seem to  have it s act together . For this reason I think that putting off the leadership decision is a mistake. Whoever is elected to lead the party will need as much time as possible to be in the media headlights. There will be as much dirt slung at him/her as the CPC can find and makeup. The longer the leader is in place, the better to counter such negativity. The LPC seems to have reacted in a knee-jerk fashion, 1st with replacing Dion and then with letting Ignatieff resign. The sooner we have a leader and we rally behind him/her we will be a contender in the next election. For those who commented that we should just wait and let the NDP & CPC make a mess, what if they don t? Harper was found in contempt, and that rolled off him like water on a duck s back. We cannot sit back and wait! We need to make the changes being suggested here to how the party operates, to bring in more young people, to simplify and to start campaigning for the next election NOW.

I m wondering how the democratic process is utilized in selection of delegates for the convention. I ve submitted my name as a candidate and today I ve received the e-mail notifyfing me that a selection meeting of our ERA was cancelled as delegated were selected by acclamation. I m not aware that I m a candidate. Therefore, how it s possible that a meeting was not required?

Hi Jarek, In response to your question, as stated in the Constitution, every riding can send up to 20 delegates to the June 18 extraordinary convention. However, since some ridings did not reach this number while some ridings had more than 20 delegates, we were able to backfill across the country. Hence, if you submitted your Notice of Intent to Stand as a Delegate form in time, you are officially a delegate on June 18. Congratulations and thanks for your involvement!
I m in the same situation as you, Jarek Walter. I m assuming we ve been acclaimed and that we ll be notified sometime next week that we re acclaimed.

Same state of confusion here as is for Peter Maloney and Jarek Walter.The email I received even has the phrase  However, you can still participate  which certainly does not suggest that I will be participating as a delegate. Organizational and communication problems?

To Blais, Peter, and Jarek  We apologize for the confusion. The email you have received was sent to all Party members. It is correct when it states that all delegates have been acclaimed and are confirmed. Delegates to the June 18 extraordinary convention will receive a separate confirmation. If you have submitted your Notice to Stand as a Delegate form in time, then consider yourself an acclaimed delegate and expect your confirmation shortly.
Thank you Andre for the clarification. I too was surprised at the email I received.

Hi to James Curran and thank you for bringing up the National Presidents name. Mr Apps has been with us since 2004 and really hasn t made much of an impression in our losses since then. He changed the rules, whether we like it or not, for the Coup D Etat to get Iggy in, surely must have been aware that that Iggy was a no starter and failed to read the feelings of thew membership and of the voters. As James has pointed out on my birthday, May 30th, I waited for Mr Apps s announcement for the October 2011 Leadership vote? In my opinion when the National President cannot or will not abide by the Constitution then he should tender his resignation or be turfed. Thats where we need to start re-building, not changing the constitution to fit each and every ones  personal agenda. We need some younger minds in our next quest, the rules and attitudes have changed from the old times and we must adapt quickly. Bob Rae is ok in the short run, but he has baggage and people remember well. So, he s a no starter to lead the party into th next election. Local committees also need to pick the best possible candidates, which may mean that the existing favourite of 20 years or so may not be the best candidate to put forward and of course we have to check out candidates BEFORE THEY ARE OFFICIALLY NOMINATED, to avoid any embarassment down the road, when it is found out the individual is not quite up to snuff or has a murky background. We need to win every by-election between now and the next general election to raise the total opposition numbers so that little Steve (put on weight again) doesn t get to comfortable in his role. We ill see his true colors come out in the very near future and even cons will shiver at some of the things he dares to do. Look up, be proud of our Party and lets go forward with one objective in mind, a majority at the next election. Look back to 1993 when the Tories were a number of two: Elsie Wayne and Jean Charest, believe me it can be done without merging with the NDP and Bob bring that subject up even once and your out.

Now see, this is what upsets me. I ve just received an email advising that delegates from my riding have been chosen for the extraordinary convention on June 18th. How did this happen without consultation and discussion with the membership? Nobody asked me to either attend a meeting or volunteer as a delegate. If you want to solve problems you have to get to the root of the problem first. As far as I m concerned, ignoring the grassroots members is the NUMBER ONE problem with out party.

Successful people study the reasons for a failure before plunging ahead to the next iteration of effort. Even thinking about a leadership process without an honest discussion of why we were trounced by two other parties is a waste of time. I ve given our defeat some thought. We did not fail because Stephen Harper is a brilliant man who could out-think his adversaries; au contraire, being beaten by a weak contender like Harper is further proof that we didn t have what it takes to win and that we must determine why we failed. Two obvious reasons were that we were unwilling to confront important issues and apparently no one did a SWOT analysis. Here is a sample list of some of these issues: Michael Ignatieff did not look good on camera. Did no one in the Party Executive notice that: he had very crooked teeth/a bad smile; he looks too thin in shirtsleeves; he has a really bad haircut; etc. In politics an ounce of image is worth a pound of performance. Harper always looks like he has just had a make-over. He is overweight but his team manages to make him look him less so. Michael Ignatieff is not Martin Luther King: calling out  rise up, rise up, rise up , etc. to a crowd doesn t work for him. It was reminiscent of Howard Dean; i.e., too strange for people to relate to. Michael Ignatieff didn t address the Reform Party s attack ads; e.g., most normal people would take a prestigious job in another country if they could. It would have been easy to say, for example, that the only reason Harper didn t take a job at Harvard is that (a) he wasn t qualified, and (b) no one offered him one. Harper s lack of loyalty to Canada was amply demonstrated by his treasonous Alberta Firewall letter, which was never even mentioned by Liberals. An election is like a sale. The First Rule of Sales is  if they don t like you they won t buy from you . Most people didn t like Michael Ignatieff, even if they believed that he had a superior intellect. They could not relate to him on any level. He should have learned to like Tim Horton s coffee, etc. well before the election. Anyone who has watched the Royal Canadian Air Farce would know how important this is. Harper had many weaknesses (he is an  economist  who doesn t understand economic basics, for starters) but the Liberals failed to exploit them. Michael Ignatieff has poor judgment; e.g., interrupting a hockey game. I m afraid that there is no cure for this but experienced advisors should have revented such a gaffe. Michael s wife had six years to get Canadian citizenship, which made him a laughing stock during the campaign, as in  even his wife can t vote for him . Totally avoidable and a gift to Harper. The Liberals failed to have a concise, focused, and clear message that they could repeat consistently during the campaign. Long, rambling discussions don t result in votes. The Liberals never asked themselves the most important question:  What do we have to do to win? . The election resulted in a bi-modal distribution with the Liberals occupying the valley in the middle. The best solution may be for the Left to unite, as the Right did under Harper. Unfortunately the terms of a unification would now be dictated by Layton. It doesn t look good to me. A defeat in the next election will probably be the end of the Federal Liberal Party as a political force in Canada. And finally, does anyone in the party executive honestly believe that if Jean Chretien had been our leader that he would have lost this election to Stephen Harper? Sincerely, Hans Jacobs _ a longtime Liberal

I, too, received an email suggesting that the delegates for my riding (not named in the email) had been acclaimed. It might have been nice to have been offered some additional information _ the names of the acclaimed delegates, for example. Not unlike several other commenters, I am a new member. I joined immediately after the election. I ve been a Liberal supporter for most of my voting life and a regular donor in the past few years. I thought that it was time that I began participating more directly. I don t feel that the acclamation email is a very satisfactory or satisfying start.

I m very much a  johnny-come-lately  to the Liberal party, having been a card-carrying Progressive Conservative from the Diefenbaker days. I think the idea of delaying the leadership convention is a good one. I can remember envying the Liberal party for its solidarity when we Tories were constantly fighting among ourselves. I don t know if I was delusional at the time or if this Liberal bickering is a new phenomenon. I m interested to see that a number of people are suggesting we focus on one issue. I would disagree. I would like to suggest that we come up with a clearly-articulated vision of what we would like Canada to be and then design policies to help us attain that vision. As you can imagine, I was never a fan of Mr. Trudeau (possibly jealous of his charisma) but he did articulate a vision. It seems to me that we have become a country of pessimists and that should stop. One of the newspaper columnists here in Toronto made the comment recently that Mr. Harper sets the bar low so that he will not be forced to break promises. This is sad. If we don t set the bar high, what do we have to strive for? I do think Mr. Ignatieff was badly advised during the election. People seemed to be trying to turn him into something he is not. Hopefully whoever becomes the next leader will have a better (more supportive?) team around him or her.

This is the way I feel. 1. I will be happy to support the two amendments if the following conditions are understood: we must use this opportunity profitably and with a purpose to re-form and revitalize the Liberal Party, so that we can come to the next election saying with confidence,  Look at us now, Canada!  Included in this would be to: -develop our use of social media to increase membership, improve fundraising, attract young voters, and improve communication among Party members; -bring the Party constitution and mission statement up to date; -identify and develop the participation of Liberal candidates to run in the next election; -and identify and develop candidates for the position of Party Leader, to be chosen during the Leadership Convention in January, 2012. 2. I feel that the most desirable attributes to look for in a leadership candidate include the following: -a strongly developed sense of patriotism is vital; -a strong character who can retain his/her composure and work effectively in an extremely challenging, sometimes negative, work environment is also essential. Also required are: -a basic selflessness of personality; -an ability to envision and articulate short and long-term goals, both for the Party and for the country; -the possession of an intelligence that can see things from many perspectives, and make good choices (to  think outside the box  and act effectively); -the ability to consider counsel from many sources, sort the best from the rest, and to make the best decision. 3. We might also wish to consider whether it is in the Party s or the Canada s best interest for us to  un-split  the left vote, that is, to merge with the NDP, if they wish to, as the right did (Conservatives/Progressive Conservatives/Reform Parties) in the early 2000s. Whatever paths the Party decides to take, after this hiatus we must come back to the Parliamentary table a fully functioning, active party with clear goals and directions. We must all work together to achieve these goals. Jennifer Cawthorne Scarborough, ON.

Let s reframe the debate around the kind of country we want to live in and contrast it with the way things are working now. Job creation is our number one priority and there are unrecoverable opportunity costs in making the wrong investments. Invest in the people. Let me first premise my discussion by reflecting on the financial meltdown. The lessons of the free market meltdown appear to be lost. I hope that all may see the wisdom in a balanced approach to the marketplace (i.e. a more equitable split of public and private services and an enhanced regulatory regime). The costs in health care have an emphasis that is wrongly placed on treating the symptoms vs. preventing the cause of the illness. The question of sustainability of rising health care costs is the wrong argument. If you change the paradigm, however, it changes the nature of the problem. We are facing a pandemic of cancers and toxic reactions because of our environment, nutrition and life styles. The first step is to stop the cause _ comprehensive environmental and consumer protections. Regulation and control, storage, secure transport and disposal of toxic substances should be a priority. James Cameron s recent point on the oil sands was a coherent one. Don t develop beyond your technical ability to deal with the polluting activity. The one value most s share is there connection to the land. It is our shared heritage and responsibility to keep our land and its waters as clean, pristine and safe as we can. I don t believe any level of governance should sign any trade agreements that don t have rigorous consumer and environmental protection clauses written into them. Government has a moral obligation to protect the land and well being of its citizens. The statistics on the health effects and lost time due to stress, poor nutrition, food and drink born illnesses reflect the need to institute comprehensive inspections and warning systems for the food chain. From my perspective, private pharmacology is the wrong business model for social medicine. There is a role for establishing crown corporations based on sound business practices generating monies for government coffers. By establishing a national public drug program and being wise stewards of our intellectual property rights, we could patent discoveries resulting from publicly funded research and development in health care and market these abroad filling government coffers instead of emptying them. This will quickly evolve into high quality, high paying jobs. We could start to accomplish this by: Revision of patent protection legislation for pharmaceuticals Gradually increased production and use of publicly produced/provided medications Increased research and development in training hospitals, public health research facilities and in post secondary institutions Increased studies and programs to establish best practices in patient outcomes A national mental health strategy (The plight of those suffering mental illness in Canada is a national disgrace) Awareness and promotion of physical fitness and mental health Reduction in work week hours More supports for workers: stress reduction strategies for the workplace flexible work arrangements shorter work week _ reduce the work week to 32 hours and drop the unemployment rate to create a more equitable, rational, relaxed society Strong, comprehensive pension support including small business and independent workers How proud our children would be if we were to establish bona fides with third world nations by exporting free medications and training as part of comprehensive aid packages. That reflects what I believe is another shared value; compassion for others and offering help where and when it s needed. Finally, let me conclude by stating that the system is disjointed with no economies of scale and bereft of very much compassion. Waiting lists are the  new normal . There are savings in having a modern integrated, health care system. The first principle of this modern system of health care should be client empowerment. That would encompass currently outlying services dentistry, physiotherapy, massage, chiropractic care among them. This new system would be innovative exploring alternative therapies and include the following: Expanded health/patient care investment in mental illness. Greatly increase the number of seats for doctors, nurses, scientists, engineers in Canada Reduce the training costs _ ensure we are training our own young people for these jobs _ a very good place to waste billions  Comprehensive db of the benefits/side effects of all treatments especially drugs Accessible, secure electronic patient health records Together, let s what our future state should be. Articulate the changes necessary to bridge the gap and implement the new system. The money is there _ through revenue generation, existing funding and future efficiencies. By acting now in the interests of what is the best thing for the nation, we can train our young people for the knowledge management jobs of the future and enhance our global position as a world leader. Let s invest in the people and the land.

A key strategy for our party would be to unite Canadians. As a Canadian living in rural Canada, I have a disavantage on receiving affordable transportation. Regulation on Air transporatation will create equality on this important front. Affordable transortation is subject to major centers. I guess centalization is benefiting the majority and creating a disadvantage to rural Canadians. i.e. I pay up to $800.00 per ticket to fly within my province.From major centers in our country Canadians can fly to international locations all inclusive for less

I support the amendments that delay a leadership convention and a biennial convention. I find that before we can have either convention it is very important for the Liberal party to rediscover itself. We need to restructure our platform, talk and listen to Canadians and do some soul searching. There are two main issues we have to address: (1) as important as social media, membership and grassroot work are, we will not be effective if we do not know what we stand for. (2) The recent elections have shown that Canadians find us lukewarm and unappealing. The next few years will be the opportunity to have important, yet hard conversations (such as those on health care, immigration, foreign policy, energy and resources). Are we ready to lead when it comes to those conversations? Or do we simply formulate answers that please Canadians? I believe in the Liberal party that stands for its convictions and fights for Canadians. And this does not mean fighting among ourselves. All the in-fighting must stop. We cannot rebuild out party, or our country if we continue this way. We need unity of minds and hearts. We all love Canada, let that love and out vision for our country unite us and move us forward. And if we do not know what that vision really is  it is time to develop it. We will not be able to elect a leader without it. We will not be able to move forward without it. But by developing and embracing that vision we will find the initiatives and resources to help Canada flourish.

To add to my comments submitted at 1:30 am: I don t really feel I have a say in the Party. I had suggested earlier that we should present to Canadians a clearly expressed vision for Canada and then design policies to help us attain that vision. I would suggest that these policies be designed in part by groups of Party members (and perhaps even non-aligned citizens, from all across the country. We are a huge country with different problems and issues in each part. If we are to do what is best for the entire country as opposed to what would work best for any single riding or region, then it is imperative that we understand one another s concerns. In this day and age of Skype, webcasting, etc. surely it would not be too difficult to set up these groups. I would like to see a sitting MP be part of each group. This person would be there to explain the political process to us so that we could understand the difficulties of governing. Apart from that, he or she would be one among equals. These groups would be made up of people of different age groups. Having become a Young Conservative at the age of 16, I understand the importance of having young men and women involved in the political process. Now that I am coming closer and closer to being 70, I also think it is important that people in my age group be heard from, but also have the opportunity to hear what the young people are thinking. If we also include the Boomers, I think I ve covered all the age groups.

I agree that time must be taken to explore where the Party is headed before jumping in with a new leader. But this must be a true effort to develop a membership driven Liberal Party. The electronic age provides a wonderful opportunity to evolve the Party into a true grassroots institution. I fear however that this extraordinary convention is simply another way for the party brass to overcome the dictates of the Constitution. Why do I have this fear? Because the executive alone established the conditions for selecting an interim leader. Members were not engaged in that decision. Why not? If the Party is to be truly democratic, members must be allowed to debate and decide on eligibility criteria for candidates for permanent leader. That includes reviewing the conditions that exclude the interim leader from being able to run. Allow members that decision and I will reassess my view that the LPC remains a clique dominated party.

HI I have been a long term supporter of Liberal policies, but after the last election, I joined the party officially to help grow Liberal support (I am in for the long haul, a 5 year membership). The first communication that I had outside the Thank You for joining the Liberal party e-mail was a telephone call for more money. While I realize that fund raising is important, I felt that at least my riding association would have contacted me before the request of money. Felt like I was just a cheque book. If we need to expand the grass roots support, I fell that the first contact after joining should not be a request for more money. Get people involved, develop relationships, and then ask for money. By the way I did donate. Regarding the extraordinary convention, after receiving the reminder e-mail about nominating yourself to attend I decided to do so, just to get involved and meet the rest of my riding association when delegates to the convention would be selected. After all who would really vote for a member who has just joined the party. Imagine my surprise when I received an e-mail today saying that I have been acclaimed as a delegate to the convention. Being new the party and an involvement in politics (other than voting), I have a question to the veterans out there. Is this common? I know the party is despondent, but not being even able to generate enough interest in the convention to require a voting process does not bode well for my riding. So taking vacation to attend I am looking forward to meeting everyone at the convention. Regards C.J. Harrison Oak Rides Markham

First, I want to commend the Liberal Party for opening up the comments section so members are free to discuss their opinions with others. I m a firm believer that the rebuild starts with the first conversation, so this is a great start. I encourage the Party to continue this practice after the Extraordinary Convention, and open the website up as a forum for members (and the public) to have frank and open discussions. I m very happy to be a delegate at the upcoming convention _ I believe it is important for the party to push back the timing of the potential leadership convention and biennial convention and I will vote accordingly on the 18th. The Liberal Party has been through what I would call a traumatic experience and it needs some time to engage with members and re-evaluate how to move forward. This is new territory for everyone and we have to figure out the way forward, but in a logical, efficient (and, I might add, cost effective) way. The Grassroots of the party are very important in this process and I am heartened by what I hear from the members who have commented. So continue the conversation _ I look forward to helping rebuild the party with all of you. Marlene Floyd Hull-Aylmer

The principle of Liberalism resides in the essence of our nature itself, in this thirst for happiness we bring with us in life, which follows us everywhere, but which however, is never completely quenched this side of Heaven. We gravitate incessantly towards an ideal that we never reach. No sooner have we reached the point we are aiming at, that we discover new horizons whose existence we never even suspected. We dash towards them, and those new horizons, explored in their turn; we discover others to which we are carried away, on and on, further always. Thus will it be as long as man is what he is; as long as a soul immortal sits in a mortal body; his desires will always spread wider than his means, his actions will never reach the level of his conceptions.  Wilfrid Laurier, 1877 I would contrast this vision of what Liberalism meant to one of the leading names in our party to the current state of affairs within the Liberal Party. There has never been a time with easier means of communicating amongst ourselves then there exists today, but instead of a greater dialog and debate we are slowly breaking apart due to lack of shared goals. May 2nd was a watershed event for our party. From the postings here we can see many new voices are joining to help rebuild the party. We need to stop seeing these new members as just sources for donations and encourage their participation in debating our future. We need to come together as a party and for that we need extra time before adding the stress of another leadership race. For that reason I support the proposed constitutional amendment. For new members looking to help rebuild the party, welcome! If you would like to help rebuild you may want to start with your Electoral District Associations. Volunteer to participate on the policy and membership committees. Set the tone you want to hear to fellow members.

Thanks for this forum. My understanding is that we re a grassroots party. Key to grassroots is communication _ transparency _ party cohesion. There s one broken communication link that I m aware of. I was webmaster for our riding during the election, but after May 2 communication with our members broke down. We d been talking to them regularly during the election using the websites and blast emails, so the opportunity was ripe to invite them to join in renewal of the party. Our candidate had just lost the election. The whole party had lost big. What were we supposed to say to them? I think it was critical to say SOMETHING to prevent members from drifting away. But we sure could have used some party guidance on the WHAT of the message. When I m representing the party in a message, I want to make sure I m getting it right. Our leaders seemed to be talking to the press and each other, but the silence from within the party to the EDA s was deafening. If EDA s are valued, if members are valued, we have to open up the lines of communication and start talking to them, especially when it matters.

I believe the party needs to consistently listen to the grassroots. Denial of such is at their peril. I believe that we need more time than the next few months to select a leader. I for one will be supporting a deferal. I have been involved in leadership races in the past, and people carry a lot of baggage around for years, myself included. Now is the time for some healing, listening, and consultation. We have to get it right, otherwise the Liberal Party may go the way of the DODO Bird. I for one don t want that to happen!

Thanks for the opportunity to speak  having been a card carrying member since I was old enough to join, off and on, and a pretty active member on the Women s Commission when I first moved to BC, I have to say that what I saw during this election was just atrocious. Kids who are carrying signs for candidates _ kicking them down the street, candidates at their  open houses  who didn t network or speak with others, and in my neighbourhood, signs didn t go up until the day before the election. Like many of the individuals who have posted, I mostly got phone calls for money. It isn t just about that is it? it s about energizing the masses, about engaging with every Canadian and showing/sharing values. All missing in the way the campaign was conducted. Since the election, not even a call from the local office to say  hey thanks for coming out , or an email from the Women s commission to say  ok, this is what we re going to do now   or   Do you have any ideas    This forum is a great idea, but the grassroots, local, personal touch is really missing.

Thank you for this great initiative and your quick response to questions being raised. Well done! I m very supportive of the steps that have been taken by the National Executive to provide members the option of delaying the leadership vote in this circumstance.I will be standing as a delegate and will support moving the date beyong the current October date. This should allow the Party membership the opportunity to start the renewal process and participate in a robust, dynamic leadership selection process.

I should add that my local candidate in the past election _ Scott Bradley (Ottawa Centre) _ has done an excellent job post election in communicating with volunteers and the membership in the riding regarding  thank you s  and details on the path forward including the extraordinary convention.

Grassroots item 2: En Famille Members are hungry for forums because they want to be part of the renewal discussion. This forum is a good example of that. The party needs to be respectful of the interest and willingness to contribute to these forums, if the grassroots epithet is to be believed. Member forums are worth far more than donations (at least if Obama s campaign was any indication). Involved members tend to donate money as well as time, but only if they know their involvement is appreciated and incorporated. When I first heard about E-F, I got involved in the discussions by inputting 40 letters. It was great fun. So many thoughtful, constructive conversations on there _ very worthwhile Then the party sent me an email saying: Send us your best idea for Liberal party policy and you may win a space at the Montreal Convention. I thought, what s wrong with this picture? Don t they know about En Famille? But I did send them my best idea, namely, please check out the 40 letters I ve already written on En Famille. Those are my best ideas. As far as I can make out, the internal leaders of the party don t value En Famille, even though the members have contributed hugely to it. And there s a very clear, albeit unspoken message in that. Are we grassroots or not?

Policy schmolicy. We went into the election with sound, supportable, policies, and great candidates, some of whom were defeated. Mike Savage, Dartmouth, was defeated by an NDP who doesn t live in the riding, and has been out of politics forever. The NDP had unsuppotable policies, and have shown the people of Nova Scotia they can t be trusted, provincially _ but nonetheless, the NDP  tide  swept through the urban area. In my opinion, it had nothing to do with policy, and everything to do with the conservative attack ads. Those had the effect of driving the voters away from a good party with a great leader,although didn t achieve the goal of driving voters to Harper, but rather to the other slightly left party. Unfortunately, voters don t really pay attention to policy, they pay attention to image.Nor do they pay attention to quality. Unfortunately, the Ignatieff image was not good. But I saw him in person in Halifax, for the first time, and he was phenomenal, brilliant, great on his feet, etc. Even the media came around, and was very complimentary. But our next leader must be charismatic. Brilliance and competence are not enough It is therefore only by chance that we occasionally achieve great leadership in Canada. But the other painful problem for our party, is that we continue to be plagued by what one radio journalist described as the Liberal  Tribes .If we don t stand behind our own leader, who will? Yet, here in NS, we still have for example,  Martin Liberals, Turner Liberals,Chretien Liberals, Cowan Liberals, McLean Liberals,Savage Liberals, MacNeil Liberals, Whelan Liberals.In so many conventions, I have supported the losing candidate, but happily put on my red hat, and happily and honestly stand behind the successful candidate . I will always continue to do so. And we all must, otherwise the fractures in the party will destroy us. Jean McKenna

The Trudeau years were this parties glory years, and the further the party got from the principles of that era, the more our support erroded. We need to listen to the party elders as they do in our aboriginal communities and understand where we have come from. Canadians are looking for a true made in Canada government, and the best example of that in my lifetime, (although I was a member of the Conservative party at the time), was that of Pierre Trudeau. We need to get the train back on the rails, we need to be unified in our unwavering vision of what Canada should be, and then we need to have a vision statement that reflects our vision for this country, and follow it.

Thank you for opening up the forum for input from members across the country. It is a valuable process and one that needs to be done. As a communications individual, the Liberal party of Canada has to immediately stop two  branding  issues as they play into the hands of the Conservatives and the NDP, namely victimization and entitlement. First, the party/MP s need to stop using  bullies  in their questions, scrums, interviews, panels, etc  This is a message that will draw comparisons and contrasts that will ultimately benefit the Conservatives. When someone calls the other a bully, it inevitably makes people go support the bully as they are more likely to  protect  and  be cool.  Now, the reality is, that is completely laughable to imagine the likes of Van Loan, Harper, Clement and Baird walking around the school yard when they were teenagers beating up kids to get a smoke. It is more likely they were picked. However, when the term  bully  is used, it is helping their  brand  with leadership, strength, and direction, even if we do not like a bully. As much as I like Ignatieff, our communications strategies with  bully  forced a contrast position that Ignatieff was the  wimp  and built the  bully  leader brand of Harper. A new leader should not be engaging in that messaging, but that it should be carried out by the key spokespeople of the party. And, if Harper s minions throw a punch, don t be afraid to throw one back using the key messaging. A strategy has to be implemented that doesn t use shrill tactics, but sharp, consistent messaging over a period of four years that will shake the  leadership  brand around Harper. Remember, the key talking points for Harper s ministers and MP s throughout the first two years was  under the strong leadership of Stephen Harper  and the use of key words like,  principled.  We cannot continue to laugh at this strategy because it works. Second, the Liberal party has to immediately stop believing that it is the natural governing party, or that it will return to power once the Harper Tories fail. This will guarantee the party will never return in the near future. What is the reason why we should return to power? We are not entitled to government. We have to make the case why, and we have to argue it on the street level. For instance, in reference to crime bill why are we not arguing the cost to the taxpayer. For instance, it costs the taxpayer $192 per day to house a non-violent prisoner in a facility with no capacity to provide rehabilitation and therefore more likely to recommit a crime. However, it cost the taxpayers $101 per day to house a non-violent offender in a transitional home where they can work and rebuild skills and are less likely to recommit a crime and thereby burdening the taxpayer. Or better yet, if my kid gets caught with a pot plant, they could face six months in jail. This would cost $192X180 days = $34,000 for one kid. Why not put that money towards prevention thereby bringing down the cost of crime. The message should be,  that s an expensive lesson for the taxpayer for something so minor.  Incarcerating minor offenses increases the burden on the taxpayer not lowering it. A new leader should not argue it is the  right  thing to do, as this comes back to the  entitlement  brand .Liberals do not have a monopoly on morality. It is not the right thing to do in Canadian s minds because we have not attached a dollar figure to it. It is the reality of today. A new leader should know the cost of a loaf of bread, love hockey, bring their kids to a football, baseball or hockey game and identifies with the bread and butter issues are of the day. Own the narrative don t follow it!

Others here have probably already said this, but this forum seems rather redundant, given that we already had an a-one forum at En Famille which was seriously neglected by the party brass. In fact, many folks here don t seem to even be aware of  En Famille . I can only hope that our new leadership and the rebuilding process will take these discussion forums seriously. There were some brilliant ideas and suggestions posted at En Famille when people were actually using it, and it languished for lack of attention by the  powers that be . I m trying desperately to be optimistic and am still maintaining my position on the executive of my riding association, but have already ceased one aspect of my involvement (our website management) because of interference and the  Father Knows Best  attitude from National. Don t get me wrong  I understand how difficult the management of an organization like this is, and I know that change can t happen overnight. It s just that change has been talked about for a long, long, time and I think we re all talked out. It s time for management to stop talking and start doing. Diane McLeod Kamloops-Thompson-Cariboo

I have just received an email from Bob Rae inviting me to become a member. I am a member. The Liberal Party needs to do some serious work in the area of data collection and targeted communication. During the election, I received at least an email a day (from Senator Grant Mitchell) advocating that I vote Liberal despite my being a Laurier Club donor _ I thought that it would be self-evident that I would be voting Liberal. Eventually I labelled the material  junk  so that the bombardment would end. If it annoyed me, what would it have done to someone trying to make a decision?

Like several of the other commenters, I am a long-time Liberal supporter who has only recently become actively involved, volunteering in my local riding and officially joining the party. We have a great deal of work ahead of us, but this beginning dialogue is a good start _ let s build on it together !

I think it is time that the Liberal Party of Canada start talking loudly about progressive ideas, such as the legalization or at least decriminalization of marijuana, and have to stand at the front of the Anti-separatist movements of Quebec and Alberta. Let our party be the unifying, nationalist party we have always been, and let s not let our country become fragmented by regionalism and right-wing / left-wing rhetoric.

My belief is that before there is a focus on rebuilding the Liberal Party, the Liberal Party should engage in the re-building of our multiple levels of government. By doing so, this could establish the direction towards an area most Canadians want to see, rather than the weary back and forth exchange of power between the Conservative and Liberal parties hat had taken place in the past. The NDP opportunistically took advantage of this, here in Quebec. As a Montreal West Islander I am in a worst of all worlds situation. From a municipal perspective I am despised by the Montreal main island (the Montreal Metro system runs East, North and South, but curiously the Montreal Transit Corporation compass does not include West), as a Provincial Liberal we are well served by our MNA but taken for granted by the party , as a Liberal riding we are part of the enemy as far as the current Federal government is concerned. If on the other hand I was in Tony Clements  riding, I would have benefitted from Multiple projects worth millions of dollars under the guise of the G8 summit. Politicians, no matter at what level they represent, should be acting on the best behalf of all citizens. Looking backwards does no good as this boils down to an exercise in who fired the first shot in the Middle East conflict. The systems we have in place are not working and as a Net-Net result Canada will slip behind developing countries. As the economies of China, India, etc as well as the number of their middle class, increase, we will find ourselves facing stiffer competition for products. As we sell off our corporations we ll be potentially faced with shortages of oil, electricity, pharmaceutical products, even food, as production here could be sold at higher profits, out of country. If we don t rid our systems of influence peddling and corruption and build the framework for a strong future, our grand-children might discover what it s like to live in a third world country without ever leaving home.

I do not think that the Liberal party is a clear choice relative to the socialists at the moment. It is not enough simply to be good. Your ideas have to inspire greatness, confidence and pride in the country and ourselves. So yes, we must help the poor, the unemployed, the sick and so on, but that is just the foundation not the future. The party needs a grand idea. Build a Canadian access to space. Or build a passenger train network serving most of the country. Or roads to the north. Or ports in the Arctic with ships to match. Or domed cities in the north where people can live more normal lives. Such ideas are only examples, but they would easily replace $100 billion dollar im ported stealth fighter planes. Such expenses are real in the sense that Canadian wealth must be traded against the imports. But money invested in our own country we can afford-this is real investment. The United States of America behaved just this way in its formation phase, with generous protectionism to boot.

I firmly believe that the Liberal party should stongly present itself as the TRUE fiscally responsible party. It is fine to propose social programs whether it be national daycare or student grants, however until our economy is truly healthy, it is  pie in the sky  to promise what can be viewed as frills by a population that is unemployed, under-employed or uncertain as to their job security. I think that by the time that the present government goes to an election, that the average Canadian will be panting to hear a platform that is honest. An appeal to love of this country would not go amiss, especially once we have had four years or more of abuses to our sovereignty _ both in questions of border and personal freedoms.

So Liberal Party Executives you say you want dialogue _ well you need to update this site to create a vehicle for better dialogue. In the next little while delegates will vote on 2 Liberal Constitutional amendments _ and assuming the amendments will pass _ there is a 7 1/5 months dead zone until Jan 2012. What is happening during these 7 months? Does anybody know? If they do it would be good to explain the plan to members. I would suggest we start talking and brainstorming NOW and not in 7 1/5 month time! I would suggest having a number of these discussions started covering relevant topics including: 1 How can the LPC executives communicate and get better information on what members and Canadians are thinking via the internet and discussion boards - how to improve LPC website and discussion board to encourage open discussions - should we have an separate discussion board open to all Canadians? - should we have a VOTE page where Canadians can vote on different topics so we can get a better idea of what Canadians are thinking .i.e. should we kill the long gun registry, etc  (and each topic you can vote yes/no _ and also have a discussion board detailing different points of view, pros/cons of bill, etc ) 2 Liberal constitution - read it _ all 80 pages! - read the other parties constitutions - you will have lots of questions! - it needs to be clear, simple, honest and to the point _ and reflect our current reality 3 Party structure - look at party structure - make more efficient 4 What are we looking for in a leader? -   5 fund raising - basics of fund raising - workshops on how to raise more funds - workshops on how to go door to door - do s and don ts in fund raising - how to more effectively raise more funds - should we add interact and monthly donations to ways of donating to party (answer is yes!) 6 recruitment of new members - do s and don ts - workshops on how to recruit ne members 7 finding qualified MP candidates - defined qualified! - training of these potential MPs - workshops on public speaking - workshops on taking to media - workshops on how parliament works - workshops on how to run a campaign - workshops on how to use data bases available to candidates  - basically preparing new candidates for MP on what to do to win an election 8 Goals of the up-coming party convention - info on party convention - structure  - costs - there should be some sort of convention agenda _ guide book 9 History of liberal party and its evolution and values 10 History of conservative party and its evolution and values - know thy enemies  11 History of Bloc and it evolution and values 12 History of Green party and values 13 History of NDP party and values Etc  and members should be able to add new relevant topics  Of course for all the topics the format should be able to accommodating sorting of comments, voting on comments _ thumbs up/down, edit/delete comments, and replying to specific comments in a discussion  Here is a challenge to the LPC executive _ you want to hear us _ give us the tools we need. And we need a time line as to when this will be up and running (anything over 20 days is too long). Get it up there and running _ don t worry you will get feedback on how to make it better! Welcome to Political Purgatory!

Alfred Apps  ideas about the expanded charter should be supported by Liberals and liberals everywhere. We don t need to be the party of big government, just the party of the big society. Rights and Freedoms need to be guaranteed, and backed, by a strong government. That doesn t mean government has to provide them. There is a big role for the  private sector.  But government does need to offer a promise to every citizen that certain rights, including those that Alfred mentions, will be provided. It is impossible to have a strong society any other way.

The most important thing that Liberals need to do is get back to the grass roots organization that we once enjoyed. Respectfully I would say that over the past decade there has been a great push from above to allow the executive to make all of the decisions. This has happened with regard to policy, leadership and issues. I do not believe that we lost the last election due to lack of good policy or lack of effective campaigning we lost the election because Liberals did not vote Liberal and I believe that happened because so many feel dissenfranchised from the decision making. If we do not fix this we will suffer the same fate over and over again regardless of leader.

I think all the future policies of the Liberal policy should take into account the need to lessen the gap in wages and incomes of Canadians. I can t see that you can have a strong healthy country if there are large disparities it is just not workable. I think Canadians would rather have a quality of life assuranceof well being and stability. Encouragement for small business Lowering health care cost6s by improving the health of Canadians starting in the schools. A realization that maybe green energy is cheap and cheap energy will provide prosperity

The leadership has to learn to LISTEN to the membership everywhere. Here in the West, we told the people behind it that the whole firearms issue had to be modified for the West. Our message was ignored, and we were little by little defeated by a silly issue that was milked and manipulated by the Tories over the past nearly 20 years. Western Agriculture has been largely ignored by the Liberal government in the last 30 or more years, and we have become a non-entity as far as that is concerned. Here in Manitoba, a few power-brokers built up their own empire at the expense of the rest of the province. I could go on and on, but to sum it up, the Liberal leadership hasn t listened to its membership, so no wonder it has lost touch with the general voting public. Get back to listening, and being the party that represents middle Canada..not the righteous right, not the loony left, but the average middle-class, middle-income people, and we will once again be the party that I have been a member and supporter of for most of my life.

To differentiate ourselves from the Tories, and save the lives of our troops in countries, we should withdraw our forces _ say  Sorry  to NATO,  but we no longer see a combat role for our troops . Why? Because our bombs are likely killing innocent citizens in Libya and to continue to  train Afghans to kill Afghans and be able to sleep nights doing it  (my perspective on it), is a preposterous foreign policy. There is strong evidence that NATO is using uranium munitions in ordnances dropped on Libyan targets. As of last week, prior to the intense bombings of Tripoli, 240 bombs were dropped via our F-18s on Libyan targets. The leader of the 3rd party should ask the PM if _ we are indeed using urnaium munitions, and what are the targets? Can he assure us that innocent civilians are not dying because of these aggressive air strikes? And can he assure Canadians that radioactive munitions (used in Iraq, the Balkans and Afgnaistan) are not now being deployed on Libyan targets? Bob K.

I believe that the riding associations need to identify their issues and present them to the  head office  , who would in turn have a committee setup to review all issues and they will see common threads and unique concerns per region. This should enable the committee to suggest to the policy committee items to be included as national policy, present them back to riding associations for approval or at an AGM. Eventually transform those ideas into a new red book written in plain English/French with examples for everyone to understand them. Use this as our platform. Also adopt the Harperite use of simple, short, scary words _ reckless coalition for example, to use and start labeling the CONs as the irresponsjble government and the NDP as the socialist Bloc in disguise at every possible moment. Start branding the CONs as only being out to pad their pockets or their friends  and show examples. Show the NDP as left sing extremists with Quebec sovereignty leanings. Help fuel Peter MacKay s fears about his  deal  with the devil and maybe that may help spilt up the right. Bring out the abortion and same sex rights boogeyman, saying that private member bills will be introduced to eliminate these rights.

First I think we need to address reasons why the party did so badly last election. One thing I noticed was poor advertising of Liberal Ideas and a poor platform that did not meet the expectations of Canadians. We need to address concerns such as: 1) Economy (promoting Canadian Industry and promote small business creation by either creating an agency to help get those that wish to start their own business and or by helping with grants.) 2) Trade (both internal and international) 3) Human rights (Labour Rights, minorities, women) 4) Military (why for example are we buying and leasing equipment from other countries, doesn t Canada have a strong industrial base so we can make our own military equipment?) 5) Promote Cooperation (and funding) with the levels of government (provincial and municipal) to create more affective economic, educational, environmental and health care plans. 6) Oversight as to why the cost of living is increasing, why gas/energy prices are jumping all over the place. The Government may need to take on a more active role in oversight and regulation. Yes we all understand that businesses need to make a profit, but there must be a difference between profit and simple greed and selfishness. 7) Job Creation/Debt assistance programs for students that are either still in school or just coming out of school. 8) Military recruitment programs: - change the physical requirements to meet more specific elements, for example the physical requirements of an infantry-soldier shouldn t be the same as a cargo plane pilot. Sure it makes things easier, but I feel the requirements should reflect the area the recruit wishes to enter. Also have a general physical requirement, then break it down to meet the requirements of specific elements of the military. (Army, Air Force, Navy.) - Pay bonuses, for technicians, engineers, pilots and Doctors/Medics 9) Senate Reform: I feel we need to approach this with a third option. The NDP want it abolished, the Conservatives want an elected senate. I think we should take a new approach. Which is Senate appointed by House of Commons committee.  Short  List made by nominations from the people who live in the region/area of the vacant Senator place. Elections Canada can keep track of the top 5 nominees. And the House of Commons Committee interviews and votes on each nominee. The one with the most votes gets appointed to the Senate. With a few stipulations, for example the committee is left in the dark on who got the most nominations and the nominee doesn t have to give what political affiliation they are. ************ On another note I felt the party was not doing enough to reach out to young Canadians. One youtube for example I found I ran into many NDP ads and not one liberal ad. How many party booths were set up at universities and colleges or even high schools? Or how many candidates actually found time to speak at the high schools or at least some of the colleges in their riding? Either way I feel more could have been done to reach out to young Canadians.

How great to have Bob Rae on my email screen me if am ready to build. I am and I am waiting to find out what to do and how to do it. So your email is a good first step. Mr. Rae, your comments on  Power Play  (Don Martin/CTV)revealed the kind of leadership I respond to most. You offered that the situation on Aboriginal Reserves as reported by the Auditor General is a  shame on our country  and a shame every Canadian should respond to effectively. You did not attack the PC s, you did not elevate the Kelowna Accord as being the total answer _ simply an indication of Liberal positions _ and I emphatically endorse your comments and style in the matter. It is a template for the kind of leadership Liberals must represent in an on-going basis. I did not join the LPC a few weeks ago simply to join a fight or refight old ideas or issues. I joined because I felt strongly that I would serve my country by participating fully in our democratic process; i.e. by becoming an active member of a political party. I am here to help build Canada, not simply fight another election, in five years or on an on-going basis. The PC party has opted for an old and proven strategy of constant campaigning, fear-mongering and power _ power tightly controlled and leveraged. We must opt for honest, open strength in taking on Canada s best interests, not our own. That can only be done at the grassroots level and I say let s get going. thanks for considering my point of view. Dale P in Nanaimo.

Thanks everyone for your participation. We are getting great feedback which is exactly what we hoped for.
