Remember to also mention your views on the proposed amendments on top of this page  some members have mentioned that they are unable to participate on June 18th due to prior engagements so it would be nice to have their comments on here. Keep it coming

I discused the problem of the poor showing of the liberal party with long term liberal yesterday. I expressed my opinion that the liberal platform was vastly superior to the NDP s (content, costing)and my surprise that the electorate had not observed this. His opinion is that in Halifax (his town) at least the party bigwigs (my phrase) had forgotten that the people who actually vote determine who is elected, while the NDP concentrate their efforts on this. Their policy might indeed be  getting the vote out  meaning people expect to be noticed _ good policy is not enough. That s certainly the case, policy-wise for the conservatives, whose policy is that of a single man (and perhaps that s true also for the NDP).

In response to Philip Chisholm s comments, said on Jun 9, 2011 at 6:02 pm  Your suggestions are well received! I encourage you to read Alfred Apps  facebook article as he describes things to come in the next 7 months ahead: http://www.facebook.com/notes/alfred-apps/report-to-the-membership-from-alfred-apps/10150213220678290. The article starts off by revisiting the events right after the elections and ends with the next steps for the National Board of Directors (NBOD).

We have to remember the  big elephant  in the room: 1) Baby Boomers aging and requirement to improve medical access. 2) Baby Boomers aging and requirement to improve government support just to survive. 3) Mental illness needs to keep coming out of the closet. 4) Fix CPP or other solution and universality of benefits for future generations to retire without fear of survival. 5) we should not be held hostage to world gas prices. Just look at the cost of litre of gas in Venezvala and Saudia Arabia.

I think the issue is whether Canadians are serious about a alternative to radical right and left parties or whether they are more comfortable with the relatively simple choice between polar opposites. The Liberal Party has been many things to Canadians over the years. We were the party of business; the party that gave dignity to Franco-Canadians and Quebecois; the party of social security and the party of sound economic policy. Do Canadians have the intellectual capacity and will to continue to want our party to pave the pathway between the extremes?

Personal: 1. I knew many people who were indecisive when it came to voting. Many of them did not see the difference between the NDP and Liberal. Most of these people were anti-conservative at heart. They did not vote, because they could not make up their mind. 2. I also knew people who were liberal, but voted NDP, just because they saw the Ontario Liberal party as the party responsible for their lose of hours at work, and also not having their incomes raised (ie. the people who worked in pharmacies). Even if the liberal party was not the responsible party with regards to this, they had been disappointed at the party for what they felt was the party s wrong doing. 3. Some others who I spoke too originally wanted to vote for the liberals, but they accused the liberals for nuisance. They claimed that the party s representatives kept bugging them and pushed for votes. This made them vote for parties other than Liberals. Domestic: 1. Living in Downtown Toronto during the Olympic games, I witnessed a general sense of pride amongst people of every race and colour, regardless of their status in Canada, whenever Canada won something. People used to pour into the streets and dance and celebrate. I feel that it is extremely important for Canadians to feel that way. In order to have better outcomes in our voter turnouts we need to make the voters feel like this country is their real home. Unfortunately, many people who live here feel that Canada is only their second home. A safe-house where they can grow and flourish and become someone who can improve the lives of the people in their  real home . Canada should become the place that Canadians miss when they are away from her. 2. Future Canada is going to be strategically challenged for her resources in the Arctic. It is our responsibility to be able to defend our borders. This means we need a stronger economy, and a much stronger home-made technology. We need to improve our industry and rely more on ourselves rather than being dependent on powers around us. We should be the ones who export technology. 3. Education is the most important factor that causes progress, and will directly effect the future of a country. It needs to be taken more seriously. More money needs to be invested in this area. A Canadian university student should not be forced to take part-time job in order to be able to pay for the continuously rising university fees. University should not be a business. University is the place where the future of the country is built, not the place where a hand-full of business men become rich. Global: 1. We need to preserve our environment. It is essential that we do not destroy our surrounding. Once the environment is gone the country will slowly start to decline. Environmental concerns are not only regional, but also global. Therefore, we need a global organization to effectively function and prevent further destruction of our planet. 2. We are entering a post-modern age, where nation-states are slowly being replaced by regional, and eventually continental unions. A global federation is not far from reality, but are we ready for it? We need to help and improve the level of every state around the world, so that they are compatible with one another. This will establish a balance of power, where everyone is truly equal. Whether we like it or not, globalization is upon us and we need to ensure that we are all ready for that. Canada is a small form of a global community, where people of multiple cultures and backgrounds have come together and are living in a relatively peaceful society. Even though Canada is not perfect, it should be considered as a working example by the communities across the globe, in order for them to resolve their issues and come together as simply humans. This will bring prosperity and progress to the humankind as a whole. 3. Canada should indirectly promote liberal and democratic values. Direct intervention in countries such as Iran is only going to cost the democratic movements in such countries, as they will be labeled as  spies of the west . We need to find democratic societies in these regions that share more cultural values with the  targeted  societies. We need to improve these democratic societies and make them an example for the other countries. Once the democratic  achievements become obvious all other societies in the area follow suit.

It is my humble opinion regardless of who becomes the next leader, unless the Party executive enact ALL of the changes suggested in the Commission For Change report, I believe our party will continue to founder. There are concrete suggestions tabled, some I know were instituted just recently, but it was too little, too late, imho. I was one of those who never or rarely received responses to my emails, (locally and from Party HQ), was flooded with constant emails soliciting funds(even though I contributed at the leaders dinner, during the campaign, and am a Victory Fund member), and quite frankly, was never really encouraged as a new Liberal to get involved save prior to the election. I was not informed of my local AGM (this approximately six months after I had joined the party!) It sorely tested my committment to the party. I noticed about four months prior to the election, things had started to improve. Town halls actually made me feel part of the party, and I noticed that correspondence to HQ was at least being answered. My question is, if the executive had two years to implement these recommendations, why didnt the executive do it? ..I know change takes time, but the executive could have acted on a few of the key ones. If the executive had, perhaps the unfortunate result of May 2nd could have been improved upon. http://cdn.liberal.ca/files/2010/05/change-commission-report.pdf Please know this is constructive criticism. But if this party is to ever achieve Govt again, it is imperative the party brass start listening to the grass roots. The old days of making a few phones calls are, as we all know, long gone. Platitudes are not what we need .Action is. Sincerely, Patrick Hamilton
I believe the amendments stated above are appropriate for this time.

Regarding the proposed motions to amend the constitution: I am in support of the motion to defer the leadership selection until at least January 2013. The party truly needs time for the membership to have a genuine dialogue amongst the members first. Clearly, setting a consensus on identity, direction, values and purpose is needed before a leader is chosen who will then help to move the party towards the fulfillment of the vision. That vision may well be very similar to the vision that currently drives this party, ..but confirming that through authentic conversation is just as valid as the development of a new vision. Regardless, ..vision & mission first   leadership to light the way second. Secondly, it would be unfair to put a new leader that does not have a clear party focus behind him/her out on the front bench in Parliament there to be chewed up once again by the unrelenting and misleading Tory attack machine. Let Jack & the NDP fight that battle for a couple years before we set a new permanent leader in the front bench. As a party we have done a very poor job of protecting both the integrity and reputation of our last two leaders. We need to know how to play the game better before we do the same to a third permanent leader. Mr. Rae is a veteran of many battles with very thick skin, sharp mind and a hardened edge. He is without a doubt the best person to  hold the fort  while the membership regroups and established a strong plan of action. We should be thankful that he is willing to make this sacrifice on behalf of the party at this time. My only hesitation on the motion as it stands is that I believe January 2012 may still be a bit early to roll out a new permanent leader. While it does give the newly chosen leader significant time to allow Canadians to get to know him/her, it also allows for significant time in which the new leader s reputation and credibility could be severely damaged. If we are not very well prepared to address this very predictable action by the Harper hacks when we do finally choose a new permanent leader, this will happen for a third time ..and no amount of policy, mission or vision will fix that!

In preparation for the June 18th meeting I ve been reading Alfred Apps  June 2011 report to the membership. Since Mr. Apps says he wants open dialogue, I m sure he won t mind me saying that his report spends way too much time fighting old battles, defending the indefensible, and advancing his own positions and point of view. Mr. Apps idea of revitalization is   to focus aggressively and especially on re-engaging women, youth, Aboriginals and new Canadians with a very special and concerted attention to Quebec. They [Liberals] want to say goodbye to a Party dominated so heavily by  middle age white guys  .  Gosh, if only we d thought of that before! Two things are wrong with this approach. The first is that it s just tinkering. It suggests that all we need to do is make some adjustments in our demographics and all will be well. That s simply not our circumstance. Secondly, it sets up a straw-man (those nasty middle age white guys) to target. We need all hands on deck to bring us  round from our recent near-death experience. As inviting as it may be to look for a diversion from the real and fundamental problems we have as a Party, I suggest that looking for scapegoats and generational quick-fixes is not going to lead us to the long-term solutions we so desperately need. Roy Derric Okanagan Shuswap

I think it is great that party members are engaged and contributing to the renewal of the Liberal party. I will not be able to attend the convention, but I do support delaying the leadership vote until sometime in 2012-2013. Unfortunately, Party leaders have become the main focus and many are voting based on the leader and less on policy. We need the time to engage party members and to fundraise. If we get the leader right, and come up with a clear and coherent message to present to Canadians, I think we can win back government in 2015. Michael Ignatieff was framed by the Conservative party, and their attack ads worked wonders. We need to level the playing field when it comes to fundraising. We are lagging behind the Conservatives and as a result the Liberal party was not able to respond to the personal attack ads waged against Mr. Igantieff. I thought that Canadians would not buy the ads, but I was wrong. I think that Mr. Ignatieff would have been an excellent Prime Minister. Leadership will be a big part of renewal, we need leadership that will listen to the grassroots level of the party. We need a leader who can best represent Liberals, while also connecting with the younger generation who will someday be the future of this party. We must plan for the future and do our best to engage as many Canadians as possible. We must work hard and take nothing for granted. I would like to thank all those who are volunteering their time and efforts to help rebuild our party. As party members, we are not always going to be in full agreement on all issues and that is a good thing, we need healthy criticism from time to time, but it is important that we remain united and open minded. Together we will succeed in gaining support for a strong Liberal vision to once again lead this great nation. Thanks

Hello all, I m very new here; joined election night (May 2) actually. I simply do not want to see my  voice  erased in the Federal sphere, therefore I decided to declare my allegiances and get involved! To the matter at hand, with the information I have to date, it seems reasonable to me to delay the leadership convention, therefore I support the resolutions put forward. HOWEVER, as a newbie, I want to put forth my observations, with some suggestions for improvements as we move forward. 1) I joined May 2 and have yet to receive a membership card or any  how to be a Liberal  information package. I believe a confirmation email said I could expect something in the mail. It s 2011. Perhaps an option to receive said material via email, or a password to a  members-only  section of the website where such materials are housed would be more timely. It would help me get up to speed on party rules & regs, opportunities to get involved etc. 2) I entered all of my particulars when I joined _ i.e. where I live! I would have thought a near immediate letter of welcome from my local riding association with some  hey, here s some local events you may want to come to  should have followed. While we can communicate and share material virtually, we are still a party of human beings and should make that human connection quickly. 3) This extraordinary convention is a bit frustrating. I appreciate the need for it, and I m glad to see so much encouragement to participate, but I still feel quite  lost . For example, I was interested in participating, but I have small children and have made no connection yet with anybody in my riding association. So, picture this. You are asked to sign up for a teleconference that will occur at an unspecified time and last for who-knows-how-long on a certain date. No idea on the logistics of the phone call, but those will come. You have to list yourself as a certain  type  of delegate, but since you don t know anybody in your area, you have no idea if you re the only one in your riding, or if there are 500 people like you, and none (or all or any) of them agree with you. So, you decide not to put your name in because you just don t have enough detail you can live with that you re new here. Then, you get a letter from your riding telling you all delegates have been acclaimed, but the letter doesn t tell you who they are, or even if we met (or are significantly below) our delegate quota. How are  we  the members of the riding to inform  our  delegates of our preferences in this convention? Apparently a non-issue as we don t know who they are, so it seems  delegate  is a loose term more like  pre-registered voters . How will these mystery  delegates  vote? I guess I ll find out some time after June 18. For a party wanting to embrace grass-roots and transparency and all of those other lovely buzz-words, we re clearly not there yet. Looking forward to continued discussion I m going to check out enfamille.ca as suggested by someone else here. We need to do more than just virtually discuss however. Perhaps some of these discussions need to move into our ridings and gel into resolutions/policies for the next convention. Perhaps that is how things already work, but like point #1 says, I m not in a position to have a clue yet .

Just an idea regarding Senate reform: Has anyone thought of the  German solution  or a version of it, namely a second chamber made up of members of the provincial legislatures? Seems to work rather well over there

Firstly, I support the proposed amendments. We need time to think and discuss policy and values before we choose a leader to carry those forward. Bob Rae is a fine interim leader and while the NDP are the official opposition, we can enjoy a bit of benign neglect in the public eye while we pull things together. January 2013 would give the new leader two and a half years to start building his/her profile in the House. That s a good timeframe. As for concerns voiced here that choosing a leader that early would give the Cons too much time to smear the new leader: Respectfully, this is nonsense. We re not going to form another government by hiding from fights and unveiling our leader the day before the writ is dropped. (Anyway, you can rest assured that Harper s people are going through our bench and putting together strategies for trashing each and every one of the possible leaders.) Our last two leaders were smeared unfairly, this is true. We re going to have to get better at anticipating and fighting back against this. But to lay it all at the feet of the Harper smear machine is to overlook the fact that our leaders had real weaknesses, and by extension so did our leadership selection process. I say this with the utmost respect and admiration for Messrs. Dion and Ignatieff, who I believe would have been fine prime ministers. But to become prime minister you first have to win a federal election. Mr. Dion s lack of facility in English put him at a critical disadvantage in communicating with the anglophone parts of the country. (The same reason, but w/r French, is why_with great regret_I was unable to cheer for Gerry Kennedy in 2006.) Our next leader needs, among many other things, to be fluently bilingual, able to *own* a debate in either language. As for Mr. Ignatieff: I was shocked by the animosity against him that I heard while canvassing. But I also never understood why he was the favourite of a small but intractable plurality in the 2006 leadership convention. And I understood even less why, once we lost the 2008 election, there was a rush to crown him. It was as if the cadre who supported him the first time around managed to persuade everyone (weary, condescending voice here)  Okay, you ve gotten your chance to play your little not-having-Iggy game, now can we just grow up and get down to the serious business of putting Iggy in charge?  Yes, if you squinted, you could consider him the second coming of Pierre Trudeau (the philosopher king) and Mike Pearson (the foreign affairs genius.) But in practical terms, he had been out of the country for far too long and he had just been parachuted into the safest riding in the country and had never undergone a real election. To be blind to these flaws_especially the second one!_is hard to justify. Look_successful leaders don t just fall into your lap. It doesn t work that way. What happens is you find talent and you recruit it and you give it time to get experience and to work on its weaknesses, and then you put it in charge. All of which is to say: We have four and a half years before the next election. We have rushed to judgement before. Okay, arguably we had to; these were minority government situations and we had to be ready to roll at a month s notice. But that isn t the terrain anymore. The terrain has changed. We have a lot of challenges but we also have some key advantages. These are: (1) knowing we have time (2) being out of the public eye for the next little while, and (3) having gotten a very clear and unambiguous wake-up call that tells us beyond any reasonable doubt that what we have been doing isn t working and needs to be overhauled. These are precious gifts. Let s not waste them.

I have followed and have voted Liberal since I was much younger. I was so upset with Harper that I decided to join the Liberal party and try to help it win the recent election. However, I was quite amazed at how ignorant and non scientific the liberal approach to climate change was. I was especially disturbed by stephane dionnes adoption, whole hog, of the issue, without a shred of science to back him up. My background is in chemical engineering as well as chemistry and biochemistry. Using the skills and knowledge gained i looked at the issue from those standpoints and discovered, much to my surprise, that the IPCC and Al Gore were in fact basing their claims on unproven models and not on hard measured science. It in fact called David McGuint y office and spoke to a person there , who acknowledged that it would be very hard to get the Liberal party to abandon it s stand on climate change. If the party wishes to build a ground up based party it must have a leader who is at least as smart as I am and who can equally understand the science issues as well as there ramifications on our economy and societal issues. It is utterly foolish to jump on a bandwagon, without understanding the issues associated with the wagon. I am terribly disappointed in the whole issue of climate change and how badly it has been blamed on the wrong thing. I have been studying these issues for the better part of 2 years now and from all the data available it seems more likely that our climate is affected by sunspots more than it is by anything humans can do to it. Bad science can be like lies spreading around the globe before thruth gets its shoelaces tied., to paraphrses Mark Twain. I am willing to debate anyone anywhere about the issues of climate change and why this party should revise it s policies to reflect the truth and make them our own. The Conservative party s stand is unfortunately the correct one but it like the liberals doesn t know why. and cannot elucidate it . We need to focus on our past successes and bring them to bear on future possibilities. We also need to establish and reaffirm our core priorities and build upon a solid foundation. This did not happen in the last election . We can take advantage of Mr. layton s adoption of the climate change to recover the seats he was able to take from us. It is my opinion that we need a leader and leadership which can understand and elucidate our policies clearly and without any misgivings, by knowing and understanding the facts of any and all issues.

We need an effective strategy to win back voters and seats lost to the NDP. People have gotten the wrong image of the Party and that has to be changed by reaching out to the grassroots. We have to be projected as a viable alternative to the NDP and a strong challenge to the Conservatives. The Conservatives are unrealistic in thinking they can balance the budget in just three years and when that does not happen we have to be there to point out the policy flaws and their game of deception. The people have to understand that politics is not a shell game it starts with listening to the public and doing a serious reality check to not overpromise on policies or any issue. We need to formulate a strong environmental policy as well as economic policy. The choosing of a permanent leader should not be put off for too long; the date ranges are realistic as proposed in the constitutional amendments but it is better a little sooner than later so the public has more time to get to know this leader and gain confidence and trust. We need a strong diplomatic leadership that will win the respect and support of more Canadians.

I don t see where there s an option on this page to reply directly to authors, so I just wanted to say to Tanya Misak and to Tim Moerman that I strongly agree with the points you raise. Tanya, in particular, your comment regarding the fact that your local riding association has made no effort to contact you (much less to welcome you into the party!) is one that is particularly important to me. I was involved in my local riding association a few years ago, and I would BEG for contact info re members in our riding who had newly joined. I really wanted to welcome these people, and to find out what had motivated them to join the party (people, I think, generally don t make the decision to join a political party unless there s one or more policy issues they think the party is most likely to support, and I wanted to get a sense as to what those issue were in order to advance policy ideas up the chain in the party). But, I was repeatedly told that such information wasn t available to the riding association. This was only one example of the lack of interest I thought was exhibited in the party with respect to forming some meaningful bond with its grassroots. Frankly, I will say that I was almost never asked my opinion on any policy matter, despite the fact that I have been a practicing lawyer and have several advanced degrees. Really, people were just more interested in my money, or rather my connections to it, as they seemed to feel that the only thing wrong with the liberal party was its lack of funds. So I left the riding association executive, and let my membership lapse (though I ve since renewed it, as there s really no other party which is capable of reflecting my fundamental beliefs). Comments like those by Tanya and Tim make me realize that I can t give up on this party, as there are clearly people who care about the party despite the fact that, frankly, the party has acted for several years as though it doesn t need to care much about those who support it. So, thank you both.

I have some very strong opinions on the future of the Liberal Party of Canada. Unfortunately it is difficult to put in a short few words my concerns and hopes for the party and for Canada. Ironically (I think that s the correct use of the word ironically :-) ) just today there is a post on the American Website DailyKos that really captures exactly my thoughts on the future of liberalsim and progressivism. These are the exact principles that I believe the Liberal Party of Canada MUST adopt once again (or maybe actually for the first time). http://www.dailykos.com/story/2011/06/09/983372/-The-Failure-of-Liberalism?via=spotlight Thanx for this opportunity to express my beliefs.

I am profoundly disappointed in the results of the recent election but have great hopes for the Party as we move ahead over the next 4 years. In response to Mr. Apps  plea for input, I urge the Party to implement a project to stimulate local militants and prepare them to undertake a major drive to build awareness and increase Party membership. To do this I suggest the following: Prepare an information package that local riding association members and supporters can use to inform friends and neighbours of the values and intentions of the Liberal Party. The package should contain points to discuss with potential members/supporters in order to help them understand why the Liberal Party is their best choice. Some things that should be included in the information for local workers to pass on are: a. what the Liberal Party stands for (in straight forward one and two syllable words), how specifically it has implemented this philosophy in the past and how it intends to promote it in the future, b. the benefits of membership in the Party, c. income tax treatment of membership fees and donations to the Party, d. how they can participate in the promotion of the Party, e. information tailored to specific regions on how Liberal beliefs and policies relate to local issues, and for Quebec residents in particular, f. frank and open discussion of the Liberal party history including the sponsorship scandal (still our main stumbling block in Quebec), g. how a Liberal majority government would deal with Quebecers  aspirations. As part of this move to spread the Liberal word and bring more people into the Party, local workers would need some form of hands on training to prepare them to meet people and carry put the task I propose. This is necessary to avoid gaffs and to maximize the return on workers  efforts. In addition to promoting the Liberal party, workers on the ground must also be attentive to the needs and aspirations of those with whom they come into contact. The workers must transmit what they are hearing back to their riding association and be able to follow up and bring accurate replies back to voters who have asked questions. The essence of the above information should be prepared in a concise pamphlet that workers can leave in the hands of those they contact along with a membership form and information on local contacts (ideally of course, the object would be to sign up new members on the spot). A campaign based on this proposal should be begun as quickly as possible in order to capitalize on the bewilderment of voters following the May 2nd election. Permit me to state the obvious: brevity and clarity are essential here, since many people will not take the trouble to read through a long, pedantic discussion of political philosophy. Local riding associations, being the ones who will implement this program, will need to be helped to prepare for giving the required training to their workers.

I believe one of the most important things that the Liberal Party can do is increase internal democracy of the party. We also must aspire to do as the Conservatives have done, which is to create a core of Conservatives only voters. These are the militants that will talk to others about our values, fundraise, donate and promote. The next thing is to give up the left and head back to the centre. There are simply not enough votes there. This does not mean that we become Conservative-light. Lastly, although some other members have mentioned that policy is not the issue, I believe that it is. Coming from rural northern Ontario, I found policies that answered to people s everyday wants and needs simply did not exist. Look to our history and step away from the shift to unfetered capitalism. We can be both business friendly without giving up our environmental heritage and destroying the middle class at the same time. And on a personal note, I was one of the few Canadians to have donated to a political party. A phone call thanking me and asking me for my time would have gone a long way to feeling connected to the party. Think of voters as customers and build up some loyalty.

Dear participants,  I would like to thank you very much for sharing your research, experiences and perspectives to the debate on eradicating poverty and leaving no one behind. This lively and rich discussion has touched upon many of the key issues to be discussed in the upcoming ECOSOC session.  For those who are just joining the e-discussion, you will find below a summary of the comments posted during the first two weeks. If you had not done so already, I encourage you to have your say and join the discussion.   This report summarizes the first two weeks of the global e-discussion for Thematic Window 1 on eradicating poverty and leaving no one behind, with over 120 responses from all regions of the world.  Leaving no one behind in the effort to eradicate poverty is to return to the essence of our humanity. Even when growth lifts millions out of poverty, many will be left behind unless explicit policies are implemented with this aim. Yet poverty reduction efforts are not likely to be sustainable unless they tackle the underlying drivers of poverty such as exclusion, vulnerability, and environmental degradation.

Poverty and development is very much interwoven with the nature and type of governance. Democratic and inclusive governance may be an effective system against poverty and drive force for inclusive development both at macro and micro levels. .However we need to highlight on the following steps:1. Enhancing human resource development through measures on education, health and livelihood generation. Initiating appropriate skill and vocational training programmes in relevance to technological, entrepreneurship development.2. Developing a registry of skills and skill exchange mechanism to generate appropriate demand and supply in the market.3. Enabling measures for access to credit and finance from relevant agencies may be for enterprise development.4. Strengthening farm and non-farm sectors as pivot for employment generation and enterprise development.Besides macro policy initiatives need to be monitored and implemented at macro-micro continuum to achieve the desired result, i.e. poverty eradication and inclusive development.

To add to the notes on adjusting policies to support co-operatives, I would like to highlight the specific ways in which co-operatives serve as tools for eradicating poverty and how the UN and its Member States could support their development in a practical way.Firstly, co-operatives can be a self-help solution for people to pull themselves out of poverty when external economic opportunities are scarce. Individuals can identify the gaps in a community (whether that be farmers' access to markets, sources of capital for small-scale loans, a food retail outlet, etc.), and form a co-operative to address that gap in a democratic, principles-driven space. Through the power of the collective, co-operatives allow people to create their own opportunities where few others exist.Secondly, co-operatives have concern for community at their core, being member-based organizations. Without the pressure of shareholders to focus on the bottom line, co-operatives are businesses that reinvest in their communities while securing the livelihoods of their members. Examples can be seen in how co-operatives reinvest revenues into building schools and educational programs for community members, offering professional development opportunities, or developing more environmentally friendly systems for waste and energy use. This means that co-operatives can not only eradicate poverty among individuals, but also contribute to the greater wealth of communities as a whole.Regarding the policies that need to be adjusted to achieve the SDGs, it would be ideal for the UN to better include the co-operative movement in global policy making processes to reflect their important economic and social impact, and for UN Member States to review their national/regional legislation related to co-operatives and consider making it easier for co-operatives to be established and to flourish. This would include provisions to make financing more accessible to co-operatives, which is one of their most significant challenges, given the lack of understanding about the unique co-operative identity.Opening the door for co-operatives to grow is a win-win situation: Member States can see greater achievement of the SDGs, and co-operatives can better meet the needs of their members and communities.

The United Nations Sustainable Development Agenda have identified 17 goals with 169 associated targets, and has set Goal 1 and Goal 2, as priorities. The aim of Goal 1 is to end poverty everywhere in all forms by 2030 during the next 15 years, and the aim of Goal 2 is to end hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture.Based on a report published by the Corner House, a non-governmental organization, the goals, though ambitious, are achievable if corruption alone was eliminated. Specifically, it is reported in the article entitled   ìExporting Corruption   ñ Privatisation, Multinationals and Bribery,  ù that   ìwestern businesses pay bribes to the tune of $80 billion a year   ñ roughly the amount the United Nations believes is needed to eradicate global poverty.  ù   Such greed mimics current politics in the U.S. to increase the wealth of the rich while robbing $800 billion from the poor. In addition to eliminating corruption and greed, according to Susan George, in her   ìA Fate Worse Than Debt,  ù (New York: Grove Widenfeld, 1990, pp. 1143, 187, 235), structural adjustment policies prescribed by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank gravely contributes to poverty worldwide; especially, for small countries.   In particular, it is noted that the IMF and the World Bank  »s structural adjustment policies and practices, which are comparable to loan sharking in the U.S, impose rigid   ìpre-conditions  ù on small countries in order for them to receive funds, creating an inherent imbalance of power.  Moreover, Susan George stated the food aid provided by developing countries amounts to   ìfood dumping,  ù further impeding economic growth by controlling smaller countries and forcing small farmers out of business through   ìmonopoly capitalism.  ùAdditionally, based on a report entitled,   ìDifferences in Anti-Poverty Approaches in Europe and The United States: A Cross-Atlantic Descriptive Policy Analysis,  ù by Koen Caminada and Megan C. Martin of Leiden University,   ìin all OECD countries, public cash benefits and taxes significantly reduce poverty.  However, the report notes the   ìpolicy goals for reducing poverty rates are rather vague and do not aspire to a specified target on either side of the Atlantic.  ù  It would also be noteworthy to review the policies of Iceland, Finland, Cyprus, Norway and the Netherlands, who actually have the lowest poverty rates.In essence, new policies must enforce and implement international trade and human rights laws prohibiting unequal trade, ensure vulnerable countries are not disadvantaged by developing countries, and policies must institute consensus-building and transparency.

Dear Pedro Conceicao, In my opinion when we talk about leaving no one behind, we should not forget all who are suffering from mental health issues. I call this double poverty: the marginalized persons in a society are confronted besides of their physical poverty with stigma. There will be no health without mental health and this is true for developed and emerging countries! It is clear from the WHO statistics that mental disorders are the biggest cause of diseases in the world even higher than cardio-vascular and cancer diseases. Unfortunately in the global development agenda mental health gets a very low priority. There are signs of hope like the joint collaboration between World Bank and the WHO and some governments (Belgium, Canada) are making efforts to address the issue of mental health on the Global Political Agenda.  Best regards Prakash Goossens, Fracarita International

On povertyPoverty is not the same in affluent and poor countries, calling for different strategies. However, as today the majority of poor people are living in mid-income countries, for them economic growth of the country is no longer what should be the priority, but growth of the average income in this group. As described by Piketty and others, the prevailing economic mechanisms lead to income polarisation, which implies a growing number of poor, unless targetted re-distributive policies, are effectively implemented. Regarding income redistribution, this can be achieved for instance by progressive taxes financing social services; the Scandinavian countries provide ample evidence for such models. Redistribution of assets is another issue and a major challenge to be achieved peacefully.On leaving no one behindThe concept of the social protection floor, developed by ILO and UNESCO and endorsed by UNCSD Rio de Janeiro 2012 offers a basic concept. Evidence and data are available with both UN organisations. Fort UNDP as a member of the UN family, the Rio+20 results (later adoped in the GA) should be the minimum to incorporate into its policies.

Leaving no one behind' is something that one aspires for. At a practical level, there is a need for breaking it down to several intermediate steps. The usual inclination is towards reducing differences - across administrative territory, ethnicity or other socio-cultural groups, demographic segments, etc. Are there lessons to be drawn from MDG experiences to throw light on relations between differences across those segments and overall poverty reduction?

"Leaving no one behind" i.e moving together toward the development every one aspires. Let us understand the emerging "Paradigm of poverty by 2030 and beyond" to generate the policy. The inclination toward the growth and development from the bottom line paradox and multi stage development from the perspective of sustainable development is essential. We shall discuss during the discussion period.

Hello Pedro and everyone in the Group!'Leaving no one behind' - is a great thought and I am sure experts around the world would have multiple solutions to offer.I would like to focus on the strength of the insurance mechanism as one of the ways to achieving this. Insurance products are available for various purposes and social/ business segments around the world. However, insurance is often not within the reach of those who need it most. This happens due to multiple reasons. However, for the purpose of managing risk in an inclusive manner, insurance is a time-honored mechanism.I am narrowing the discussion down to 3 broad models of insurance - (i) microinsurance, (ii) social security insurance models and (iii) mutuals and cooperatives. Without getting into definitions and technical intricacies, I would like to briefly discuss these 3 models.In the 1st model - Insurance companies offer microinsurance schemes for people having low income. There are often caps based on the income of the people covered, the sum insured that can be opted or the premiums payable. Usually such policies are offered due to some sort of compulsion from the Government. However, there are insurance companies which are insuring low income populations for years at length and are able to create sustainable microinsurance models over time.The 2nd model is that of social security (cum insurance) schemes, driven by the Government, mostly with subsidized premiums and a strong social security focus. The design helps in transferring unplanned Governmental expenditure for various disaster relief situations (earthquake/ flood/ drought) to an ex-ante risk-financing model, whereby insurance companies become the first port of call for financing disaster costs.The responsibility of creating adequate healthcare infrastructure in a country and maintaining it efficiently to take care of the needs of the population is another challenge of the Government. This model helps in breaking the poverty trap by passing on these responsibilities to private healthcare providers, while the costs of financing major treatment costs get borne by the insurance mechanism.The 3rd model is that of mutuals and cooperatives. These are community based models that work on insurance principles. The major difference is that here the risk is retained and shared within the community, without being transferred to an insurance company.All these models have their own positives and weaknesses. Some models have challenges in being cost effective; some have a high probability of the insured people getting undue benefits at the cost of the insurance mechanism; some are not able to ensure fair claim servicing to the customers; while some other models allow unintended beneficiaries to benefit at the cost of the insured and insurer. Again, some models work well in particular socio-economic contexts while others may not.However, there are many success stories in all these models and with proper thought an planning, the insurance mechanism can ensure that no one is really left behind.If the group is interested in taking these ideas forward, I would be happy to share more thoughts on the topic.

The SGD implementation has been successful to a certain extent. The case of Human Rights is related to Human compassion especially where reducing poverty is concerned. Very often Human Rights is seen as something that one has to  rightfully procure. The disparity issues cannot be solved by rights only but through compassionate work from all sectors. Very often we have  voiced out that education is the solution to many problems existing today. Yet the walls built are higher to cross over because of the widening gap that exists in financing education to the poorest. Hence policy makers cannot work alone in isolation from civil groups who carry out the ventures of solving issues and know the brunt of the burden which is silently shoved off once the finite material benefits are depleted to help them. SDG therefore has to look at long term benefits, through mutual collaboration. There is a model attached  suggesting of one of the ways to look at long term issues for attaining SDG's. RegardsDr Suma ParahakaranEthics and Values Educator

Havings rights to access, e.g. water is one thing but the real right that matters is the right to make decisions about how water is used. This requires all stakeholders in the community to have their say and express their needs, not have someone impose upon them what they think is needed. The only way to overcome poverty is for (in particular rural) communities to be fully engaged in decision making about developments in their own community. The linkage between water, health and economic development must be made and long term decisions and sustainable projects must be the norm, not the rarity. The important water, energy, food nexus must be taken into account. Renewable energuies that use water in a profligate way and deplete resources needed both for people and ecosystems are not sustainable.

Hi everyone! I would like to bring to the table the issue of people with disabilities, a group that faces everyday challenges in order to get access to a number of aspects that are key to erradicate poverty - e.g. education, vocational training, employment. This is true regardless of place of living, and even social status. When compared to their peers without disability they get poor education, vocational training that do not meet the market needs (making it difficult to find a job) and unemployment rates that are much more higher than for the other groups. They also are not empowered to take part in decisions, even the ones that directly affect their lives. When thinking about the MDG we see that persons with disabilities are not mentioned in any of the 8 goals. (http://www.un.org/disabilities/documents/review_of_disability_and_the_m  _)We know that not all people with disabilities are or will become poor, but we also know that poor people are more likely to become disabled, due to a number of socio-economic disavantages.

These cluster of highly independent and innovative master-minds will work within a flexible agenda to address their targets; build their physiological and psychological aptitude to take up their rightful place on the wheel of development. Reaching them thereby to where some Governments and NGOs are wanting.

According to "President Bush quoted,   ìClearly, our children are our future  _Too many of our neediest children are being left behind  ù (www.ed.gov). Firstly Eradicating poverty and leaving no one behind  ù  we have lots to do at countries  level  we need to put some measure in to place and see what government can do for our children future. Government  »s role in education  shall be their first agenda ; making sure every child/ children have access to  elementary and secondary education. Accountability begins with informed parents, communities and elected leaders they  can work together to improve schools. The states will measure the progress by testing every child in grades 13 through 9  in reading and math,  every countries  will implement fair and effective annual tests and  international partners  will provide funding to countries  to design and implement tests.  schools that do not improve will receive extra help with planning and technical assistance. After receiving extra help, schools that do not improve may be restructured. Flexibility means that No Child Left Behind gives communities the freedom to find local solutions for local challenges. For example  _to provide more local control and flexibility, 50% of the formula funding from the following programs may be distributed among any of the programs: Teacher quality, education technology and safe and Drug-Free schools. Local Control and flexibility means money goes to solve problems, not to subsidize bureaucracy. There have been many problems such as: Inadequate funding, while the administration likes to point to the large increases in spending for the education of the disadvantaged students, funding must be viewed in the larger context of a lagging economy .

Eradicating poverty and leaving no one behind through education  will be vital to our society at large. A wide variety of issues, locally and nationally, are affecting education, and will continue to affect education until these issues are addressed and solved. Overcrowded classrooms, shortages of supplies, low teachers  » salaries, dilapidated buildings, and high substitute teacher use are a few of the issues that have affected many schools across the nation.  Even though a few of these problems have been resolved, many still remain.  These issues are determined by the location of the school and the type of school, either private, public, or charter.  The current issues in education that will influence my teaching, based on my beliefs, pertain to The No Child Left Behind Act, time management, lack of flexibility, school budget cuts, technology, and bullying. Effective in 2001, The No Child Left Behind Act  policy was proposed  in  the US to nationally test all children under the same conditions and with the same test annually in order to prevent students from being trapped in a failing school.  However, the focus on these mandated tests steered the teachings of reading and mathematics to a whole new level.  With curriculum focusing the majority of its time on reading and mathematics, scores have increased across the nation, but a large gap among students still exists   but those students who struggle, still seem to struggle.  According to  "World Bank"   reportsAround 89 million youth, ages 12-24 years, are out of school in Sub-Saharan Africa.A new World Bank report examines factors that lead to 12 to 24 year olds dropping out. It highlights six characteristics of out-of-school youth.Three policy entry points are particularly important to keep youth in school: retention of at-risk youth in school, remediation through alternative education, and integration with the labor market. The pure memorization of facts being taught under these conditions are going to negatively effect students in the long run upon entering high school, college, and their future endeavors. The benefits of The No Child Left Behind Act are currently being debated.  This Act raises concerns because it will influence me as a teacher and how I will teach.

Health and education are basic determinants of eradicating poverty. Education improves health, while health improves learning potentials. Education and health complement, enhance and support each other; together, they serve as the foundation for a better world. To be able to read, write and calculate has been acknowledged as a human right. However, more than 100 million children are still deprived of access to primary education and fewer than half of all children worldwide participate in early childhood programs. Better information helps us to make better decisions. Investing in wireless Internet technology is the way forward to tackle maternal mortality and morbidity in the developing countries. E-learning is the most cost-effective way of transmitting evidence-based medicine to the developing countries. Imagine sitting in office or at home in USA or Europe, and by interacting with different cultures we will be able to understand different customs and learn to respect the diversity. Imagine students in developing countries and the United States simultaneously reviewing the same medical curriculum and learning from each other. This is e-learning at its best in an Internet classroom, and it is the goal of our initiative in Women  »s Health and Development, title: http://www.WomensHealthSection.com; which was launched in collaboration with the United Nations is serving about 14 million subscribers in 227 countries and it is available in six official languages of the United Nations. It is indeed my pleasure to submit to you UN Documents E/2015/NGO/2 and E/2014/NGO/53Over the years, the United Nations, governments, civil societies, and individuals have put forth countless plans of action for reducing maternal mortality and morbidity. According to the World Health Organization, at least 1,600 women will die today from a complication of pregnancy and childbirth, most of them in developing countries. No technical or political approach   ñ no matter how well intentioned   ñ has ever conquered this enormous problem. What is needed is broader dissemination of medical knowledge. And Internet classrooms and initiatives such as WomensHealthSection.com, can help that goal. We welcome you on our e-Health platform; # SDGAction 1212https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/partnership/?p=1212 Please join our efforts; we welcome everyone. Thank you for this opportunity Rita Luthra, MDPresidentWomen  »s Health and Education Center (WHEC)NGO in Special Consultative Status with ECOSOC of the United NationsEditor-in-Chief of e-Health Publicationhttp://www.WomensHealthSection.com

firstly I want to object to this system of gathering information.   the United Nations, ECOSOC, UNDP, UNESCO, UNICEF, and the other 28 agencies of the United Nations MUST be better coordinated.   The United Nations resident Coordinator position is not functioning as it was originally designed and someone should inform the SG of this fact.   Having a different system for the DOnor and Receiver countries may make sense to some, but a higher level of coordination is necessary.   No where is this more important than with the SDG's.   WHile they appear to be comprehensive - they are not.   The 169 touchpoints for measurements has not been vetted nor orchestrated.  This is because of a lack of holistic thinking at the UN.  it is not rocket science to say that we need better distribution systems for food , shelter, clothing, and electricity.   at the very least education in these matters is first necessary at the UN level - then taken into the field as a best examples of solutions.   The UNSDSN organization run by Jeffrey Sachs is doing no better with the SDG's than he did with the failed MDG's.   How is it after two years and a billion dollars of infrastructure investment  that the largest initiative in education took place in Malaysia  a country not known for a broadminded education system.  there is an education problem at the UN first pointed out by RObert Muller in 1972 and nothing has been actively achieved in developing common core education across the UN system.  if thiis ever happens it ought to begin with one word - PO - as enunciated be Edward de Bono - this is a critical observation that the UN has failed to grasp at any level.   The only thing I can add is AFTER the UN promotes the use of the word and not until.

Eradiquer la pauvrete en ne laissant personne derriere c'est rentrer l'humanisme, l'humanite, en mettant de le capitalisme avec ses gros interets. Neanmoins pour que personnes ne sois derriere, il y a 3 equations que certains pays comme la France ont  fait un gros effort : La sante, l'ecole, l'habitat, nous pourrons y ajouter la nutrition. Chaque Etat doit prendre en charge la sante des siens sans exceptions. Le logement doit etre un droit pour tout etre humain tout comme l'eau et la nourriture. Si notre planete met chaque etre humain a l'aise dans ces domaines. ce ne serait plus autant honteux qu'a nos jours d'etre humain.   Mettre en avant des sujets parlant d'une liberte des peuples quand ceux-ci ne peuvent ni manger a leur fin, ni dormir dans des logements decents tout en restant incapable de se soigner en cas de maladie est tout sauf la liberte.

By the end of the first 900 days of the SDGs (September 2018), governments should identify their marginalised populations, develop a leave no one behind strategy, and begin its implementation. This could be overseen by a cross-ministerial leave no one behind working group. A high-level summit should be convened in September 2018 to share learning, change direction if necessary and monitor progress.   ¢ The first  900 days are just the beginning. They need to be followed by sustained action until 2030 to address the systemic barriers to the progress of marginalised people. Progress could be monitored by a series of    stepping stone  » targets, set every three to five years, aiming to ensure that any disparities in progress are narrowing fast enough to leave no one behind.Government should priority needs of its citizens in  every direction  by providing  sustainable programs that will help and reduce poverty and make sure no one lift behind and the international communities should review all  policies  from every countries moreover, lower income countries who faces poverty and meet the needs of marginalised people in those low income countries; bringing  thing close to those whom need of it. Government  form different  countries shall priority their citizens and corruption is one of the factors that undermined this process. We are calling  on all stakeholders  to ensure we achieved this agenda Leaving No One Behind by 2030.

"I have seen them, young kids huddled together in a corner of a refuse heap in Kakamega, KENYA. With barely enough to cover themselves, their minds dulled by sniffing glue or drinking a poisonous ethanol mix, their outerwear soiled and ragged, they live on the bare edge of survival. No one comes looking for them, no one even knows who they are. And then the little ones who roam roadways and rural pathways searching for food. Chewing on a piece of sugar cane is only a temporary fix. They suffer from many things, but today and yesterday and likely the day before they have not had a decent meal. What that does to a hungry child is physiologically, mentally and emotionally disturbing.I have witnessed the effects of malnourishment and children dangerously thin or anemic. I have talked to young people in their mid teens who due to "stunting" appeared as those aged nine or ten. Something stirs within me...a mix of anger and deep sadness."Where there is poverty there is malnutrition and systemic hunger. Poverty and hunger are virtually synonymous. The right to adequate food is a human right. So why does hunger prevail when there is more than enough nourishment and food sources on the planet? Hunger is universal. Most humans have gone without a meal or experienced pangs of hunger where a day has gone by without nourishment. Yet there are an estimated 800 million people worldwide who are chronically hungry. This is greater than the populations of Canada, the United States and the European Union combined. One in eight people do not get enough food to be healthy and lead an active life. This makes hunger and malnutrition the number one risk to health worldwide, greater than AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis combined.Presently, due to environmental factors and lack of rain in the north and northeast sectors, there is a severe drought in Kenya. The facts are that 1.6 million Kenyans face hunger on a daily basis. 80 percent of Kenya's population participate in agriculture and pastoralism. Small farm households deliver the bulk of the nation's food supply. Landholdings are small, productivity is low and most have little access to technological inputs, financial services and markets to sell any surplus produce. Poverty and hunger are for many a fact of life. The poor in Kenya are of all ages; from the very young whose mothers cannot produce enough milk, to the aged with no relatives to care for them. Landless farmers working on the fields of others and youth orphaned by HIV/Aids need increased food supply to survive. So too the unemployed living in acute poverty and the ones suffering from mental illness. Women and children remain on the front lines of hunger.The malnourished cannot fight infectious diseases due to lack of protein and vitamin deficiencies. Their food intake does not include enough energy to meet the minimal physiological needs for an active life. Wasting is an indication of acute malnutrition caused by deficiencies in iron, vitamin A, zinc and iodine. This can result in reduced physical growth and mental impairment bringing on premature death.Since 2004, CES Canada's mission to reduce poverty through education and healthcare has created better and healthier learners through a daily nutrition program. The creation of dairy and agriculture farms in schools has enabled students able to concentrate on their studies and not on mere survival. Hand washing stations provide added hygiene that can reduce up to 80% of diseases. Recognizing the importance of Agriculture in Kenyan society and realizing the impact that improved practice and technology has on the supply of food, CES Canada/Kenya has encouraged students to study Agriculture at the college/university level. CES Canada has provided university scholarships for CES grads who are completing honours degrees in Agriculture Economics, Engineering, Business and Education. The fundamental right to be healthy, grow and become productive human beings in their society depends on access to education. Yet, there remains a deeper more sacred right than that...the right to life and liberty, predicated on access to proper food and nutrition. The scourge of hunger in Kenya must be taken out, its bitter roots cut and destroyed. Educate all young people to the highest levels possible and create an ethos where farming and food production creates increased economic growth. Societies can only prosper as they rise from poverty and out of the crisis of conflict.

For us, rural communities in South-South Nigeria, many will still be left behind even after the expiration of the SDGs. The livelihoods of the people have already been compromised by a polluted environment. On top of this is the huge infrastructure gap--basic amenities such as decent housing, electricity and mobility infrastructure is still far cry. In my opinion, if we must pull everyone out of poverty in this context, we must first ensure that the people have access to those modern infrastructure, repeal the obnoxious Land Use Act and make concrete efforts at redistributing the national wealth in manner that will have the rural communities at the heart of such efforts.

I fully agree with what Helio Conte comments up here. I live in Argentina so my experience comes from many years of success and failure in our efforts. At the turn of the XXth Century Argentina had a very strong basis as far as the primary and secondary system is concerned, and this was a key factor in the deevelopment Argentina had up to the early fifties (1950's).Without strong bases in primary and also secondary Education, there can be no significant efforts (moneywise) that can effectively win the unreleting struggle against poverty. However, when cheap politics get mixed up in educational efforts, it's one step ahead and two steps back. All of you know that educational strategies require long periods. It is not a question of one governement, but a question of state policies.In 2017 efforts in the edicational field are necessary related to the Sustainable Deveopment Goals. And here there is another kind of challenge. Top and medium ranking officials may be willing to move ahead in order to comply with the respective SD GOALS associated with education and struggle against poverty. However, before they can act efficiently and in coordination with the right government departmednts, they must learn about Sustainable Development, which -if one is to judge by ones own experience-it is not something one can be taught overnight.So, to resume, yes EDUCATION is key in this struggle (health, as Helio says, cannot be separated from Education). And there is work to be undertaken at two levels: that of the officials responsible for coordinating SD GOALS with Education, Health and the Struggle against poverty, and the level where those who are the subject of our struggle need to receive proper primary and secondary education. The kind of jobs the XXIst Century is and will be offering and the gap between educated and under-educated citizens is a key consideration to be incorporated in this most demanding endeavour we are engaged in.

Good morning everybody from Buenos Aires, Argentina. I am Mauricio Lí_pez Dardaine and this will be my second try regarding adding a comment to this rich dialogue. My first one was rather long and it appears to have vanished in wide space of the Internet. So I'll make this one rather short, see if it sticks and if so comment once more.To my way of thinking EDUCATION is the key here. And regarding education there are three levels on which to operate. First, there are those officials concerned with coordinating the respective SD GOALS as far as Education is concerned; they need to learn what SD is actually about, not all do know, and this in our experience takes time. Second, there is the education of the educators at both the primary and secondary level. Third, last but indeed not least, there's those at the level of poverty which must receive the benefits of education. At this level, who is able to attend school (or send their childrens to school while their daily concern are food and shelter. And even with food and shelter, there's still the question of having an HORIZON OF HOPE based on facts. Hoe can one be concerned about the education of their children if he does know what they shall have for dinner or how they shall pay their rent.I will leave my big question marks unanswered until I know whether I'm part of this group.

How will policies need to be adjusted in different contexts to ensure that they more effectively contribute to leaving no one behind in the achievement of SDG1 and related SDGs?"Leaving no one behind " is at the heart of the Sustainable Development Objective 4. Its emphasis is on equitable and inclusive education. In order to carry out this objective, it is necessary that structural changes take place in public policies that promote equity, inclusion and overcome the multiple forms of discrimination in education in the framework of the achievement of human rights. In order to address multiple and interrelated forms of discrimination, education and training must be provided to ensure the full, equitable and effective participation of all, but especially girls and women, by removing the barriers to  access to decision-making at all levels.Education is a human right, and there are barriers for women and girls to have access to a quality of education opportunities throughout life at all levels. Addressing the right to adult education is to contribute to the creation of favorable conditions for exercising their rights, and to provide diverse knowledge to contribute to the development of society, and above all, to the establishment of peace, responsible citizenship and sustainable development."Leaving  no one  behind " means giving a important  role to adult education, literacy and lifelong education. It should be a priority in all the goals, targets and indicators of the Post 2030 Agenda. But adult education and literacy not only have to be focused on acquiring the skills for the labor market, but must be oriented towards the construction of full citizenship, especially for indigenous, Afro-descendant and rural women. Adult education, an integral part of the right to education, is a universal right, essential for achieving multiple socio-economic and cultural goals and human rights to participate in the transformative changes of  the country,  at national and local level.Education  policies should be inclusive, non-discriminatory, guarantee gender equality and fulfill the right to education of girls and boys, young people and adults as geographic location, ethnicity, age, disability, migration, marital status, and other relevant factors. This means that the planning and monitoring of ODSs must take into account the different realities of countries and regions at national and local level and include  t the participation of  the OCS , women's organizations, stakeholder groups and rights holders. The approach must be intersectional, promote dialogue and recognize indivisibility and interdependence in all human rights in the 17 ODSUsing this approach will effectively contribute to leaving  no one behind in the achievement of SDG1 and related SDGs

In Sudan, data and information on poverty dates back to 2009 (before the secession of the South). According to Central Bureau of Statistics (CBS), 46.5 percent of the population of Sudan is found to fall below the poverty line, with 26.5 percent of the urban population and 57.6 percent of the rural population falling below the poverty line. Consequently, new data on poverty and poverty mapping is precondition for eradicating poverty, leaving no one behind and reaching first those who are furthest behind in Sudan.

End poverty in all its forms everywhere if we creat better opportunities for farmers and focus on the needs, In 2015 World leaders promised to put girls and women first when they signed up into sustainable Development goals to end poverty, fix climate change and tackle inequalities, Girls are women are disproportionately affected by these challenges and are key to building resilient communities to with stand them, that's why we need to ensure world leaders and the Secretary General of the United Nations to listen to the voices of the girls and women, put them first in policies and plans

In my opinion, poverty eradication is a very serious and necessary effort to make people's lives better and make the world a better place. It should be a priority. UN's works on poverty eradication provides concrete results and this is what is needed to master a problem like poverty.Policy adjustment needs to be considered gradually. Also there should be a global strategy and sub-strategies for different regions that have different dynamics. Furthermore, poverty eradication works should be not only at the policy level but also should be concrete works that provide more certain and quick results (this should be tought like a catalyzer, too). I have given examples of what I meant in the "New Evidence and Innovations in Poverty Eradication Efforts" section.
